commit_message:
Add support for roles to credentials providers

This commit adds support for requesting credentials by a role from the
credentials providers. This entails 2 things, first adding support for
specifying roles in a test-accounts file with test-accounts based
providers and secondly adding support to isolated-creds to assign
arbitrary roles on credentials requested by role.

Change-Id: I6a0f0539d41e0cf3d04414964b289447194d2793
Partially-implements: bp test-accounts-continued
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/59/143159/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _append_role(self, role, account_hash, hash_dict): if role in hash_dict['roles']: hash_dict['roles'][role].append(temp_hash_key) else: hash_dict['roles'][role] = [temp_hash_key] return hash_dict hash_dict = {'roles':} temp_hash_key = temp_hash.hexdigest() if 'roles' in account: for role in account.get('roles'): hash_dict = cls._append_role(role, temp_hash_key, hash_dict) if 'types' in account: for type in account.get('types'): if type == 'admin': hash_dict = cls._append_role(CONF.identity.admin_role, temp_hash_key, hash_dict) elif type == 'operator': hash_dict = cls._append_role( CONF.object_storage.operator_role, temp_hash_key, hash_dict) elif type == 'reseller_admin': hash_dict = cls._append_role( CONF.onject_storage.reseller_admin_role, temp_hash_key, hash_dict) def _get_creds(self, role=None): if role: hashes = self.hash_dict['roles'].get(role, None) if not hashes: raise exceptions.InvalidConfiguration("No credentials with " "role: %s specified in the accounts file" % role) else: hashes = self.hash_dict.keys() free_hash = self._get_free_hash(hashes) def get_creds_by_roles(self, role): if self.isolated_creds.get(role) return self.isolated_creds.get(role) creds = self._get_creds(role=role) role_credential = auth.get_credentials(**creds) self.isolated_creds[role] = role_credential return role_credential def get_creds(self, id, role=None): if not role: _hash = self.hash_dict.keys()[id] else: _hash = self.hash_dict['roles'][role][id] def get_creds_by_roles(self, role): if self.isolated_creds.get(role) return self.isolated_creds.get(role) if not self.use_default_creds: creds = self.get_creds(0, role=role) role_credential = auth.get_credentials(**creds) self.isolated_creds[role] = role_credential else: msg = "Default credentials can not be used with specifying "\ "credentials by roles" raise exceptions.InvalidConfiguration(msg) return role_credential
deleted_lines: hash_dict = {} def _get_creds(self): free_hash = self._get_free_hash(self.hash_dict.keys()) def get_creds(self, id): _hash = self.hash_dict.keys()[id]

subject: Remove want_objects kwarg from nova.api.openstack.common.get_instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-02 22:27:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1ab6c63fe1abdb26b44e34af5c642f7c86c3244f', 'message': "Use want_objects=True for os-server-password v3 API index

The v2 API and v3 API's show method are already getting an instance
object, and the tests are already using objects, we just need to update
the API extension for v3's index to get an instance object.

This is part of a larger conversion to eventually only allow returning
objects from nova.api.openstack.common.get_instance.

Part of blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: Ia377c66f9e2f298e46d89f2e54d032b72fd7fa90
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-02 23:43:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/941f1b08b4b7b94ff3bd9ca2c156a485c30db04e', 'message': "Remove want_objects kwarg from nova.api.openstack.common.get_instance

Now that most extensions are getting instance objects from
common.get_instance, we can cleanup the stragglers and remove the kwarg
to verify we're using instance objects everywhere for the API
extensions.

While in the process, this also converts some extensions to use
common.get_instance rather than directly going to compute_api.get.

Part of blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: Ia377c66f9e2f298e46d89f2e54d032b72fd7fa90

commit_message:
Remove want_objects kwarg from nova.api.openstack.common.get_instance

Now that most extensions are getting instance objects from
common.get_instance, we can cleanup the stragglers and remove the kwarg
to verify we're using instance objects everywhere for the API
extensions.

While in the process, this also converts some extensions to use
common.get_instance rather than directly going to compute_api.get.

Part of blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: Ia377c66f9e2f298e46d89f2e54d032b72fd7fa90
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/38/160538/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance = common.get_instance(self.compute_api, context, server_id, want_objects=True)

commit_message:
Allow tempest to skip RO access level tests

With implementation of RO access level support in API were added tempest tests
that are run if access rule tests enabled in general.

We should provide possibility to disable them, because drivers can have no
support for RO access. In case of Generic Driver it worked because it did not
raise errors and created RW access indeed instead of RO.

Define config opt 'enable_ro_access_level_for_protocols' (list type) to specify
explicitly whether RO tests should run or not for specific share protocols.

Examples:
enable_ro_access_level_for_protocols = nfs
enable_ro_access_level_for_protocols = cifs
enable_ro_access_level_for_protocols = nfs,cifs

Change-Id: I980be81399ac7449813bbffcbe3d77b7a2036c43
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/78/161678/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.ListOpt("enable_ro_access_level_for_protocols", default=["nfs", ], help="List of protocols to run tests with ro access level."),

commit_message:
vmware: support both hard and soft reboot

Allow callers of the reboot method to select either a
hard or soft reboot.

Co-authored: John Haan <yongiman@gmail.com>
Co-authored: kwonho lee <kwonho81.lee@samsung.com>

Change-Id: Ia445dbd06af03b50547b598dd1875bd3d3b9dfca
Closes-Bug: 1422239
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/96/156496/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
ofagent: Switch to flow-based tunneling

Switch from port-based tunneling to flow-based tunneling.
This would improve scalability as a single vport per
network_type is enough even when there are a ton of tunnel
peers.

This commit makes ofagent use some of NXMs.  Namely, tun_ipv4_src
and tun_ipv4_dst.  While the use of NXMs contradicts with one of
goals of ofagent, i.e. portablity to other switch implementations,
it isn't a problem right now because tunnel port support is
OVS-dependant anyway.  There are no widely implemented standards
covering tunnel port managements.

The support of the above mentioned NXMs is added to Ryu recently.
Mention the required version of Ryu in README.

Implements: blueprint ofagent-flow-based-tunneling
Change-Id: I7e4b226c56bc549fe2feb1b0afab03cd63f3c589
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/77/130677/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: a: tunnel port (tun_ofports) rrr, sss, ttt: tunnel peer's ip address metadata=LOCAL|xxx,eth_dst=uuu set_field:rrr->tun_ipv4_dst, \ set_tunnel(yyy),output:a metadata=LOCAL|xxx, set_tunnel(yyy),\ set_field:rrr->tun_ipv4_dst,output:a, \ set_field:sss->tun_ipv4_dst,output:a, \ set_field:ttt->tun_ipv4_dst,output:a, \ goto(next table)import itertools port, remote_ips, goto_next, **additional_matches): actions += itertools.chain([[ ofpp.OFPActionSetField(tun_ipv4_dst=ip), ofpp.OFPActionOutput(port=port) ] for ip in remote_ips])
deleted_lines: a,b,c: tunnel port (tun_ofports, map[net_id].tun_ofports) metadata=LOCAL|xxx,eth_dst=uuu set_tunnel(yyy),output:a metadata=LOCAL|xxx, set_tunnel(yyy),output:a,b,c,goto(next table) ports, goto_next, **additional_matches): actions += [ofpp.OFPActionOutput(port=p) for p in ports]

commit_message:
Add test lists for defcore

Parse defcore/refstack specs to extract the test lists.

Change-Id: Ib82807b0182938c6f61156e6afd530b1f4c45ec6
partial-bug: #1426442
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/80/161680/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Generate test list from official defcore/refstack spec # Note that unlike the other test list functions, this one isn't a filter # it ignores its stdin and pulls the gest list from github. function gen_test_list_defcore(){ branch=${1:-juno} python <<END import json import requests branch="$branch" response = requests.get("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/stackforge/" "refstack/master/defcore/%(branch)score.json" % dict(branch=branch) ).json() tests = [] [tests.extend(x['tests']) for x in response['capabilities'].values()] for test in tests: print(test) END } # defcore tests for juno function gen_test_list_defcore_juno(){ gen_test_list_defcore juno } # defcore tests for icehouse function gen_test_list_defcore_icehouse(){ gen_test_list_defcore icehouse }

commit_message:
Make and symlink log directory in aio bootstrap

This patch creates the /openstack/log directory within the AIO bootstrap
script to prevent 'unstable' results in openstack-infra's jenkins.

It also moves the symlink to that directory to much earlier in the
gate-check script for the same purpose.

Co-Authored-By: Ian Cordasco <ian.cordasco@rackspace.com>
Closes-Bug: #1428744
Partial-Bug: #1425482
Change-Id: Ib74b5fd216d43e74ca264c14818cfef6e2dc0c70
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/60/161660/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Implement the log directory link for openstack-infra log publishing ln -s /openstack/log $SYMLINK_DIR

commit_message:
Mention --segment-size option after 413 response

Previously, it would only output something like

  ClientException: Object PUT failed <url> 413 Request Entity Too Large
  Your request is too large.

... which is misleading as it implies that Swift simply can't handle
large objects.

Change-Id: Icec9e76b2671490c3a2249ec08992950107c6828
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/66/161966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: too_large = (isinstance(error, ClientException) and error.http_status == 413) if too_large and options.verbose > 0: output_manager.error( "Consider using the --segment-size option " "to chunk the object")

commit_message:
Use Container override header to update etag and size

Add two new headers to ec footer message to override
the etag and size values when updating
the container servers.

In the case of EC, the object server calculates the
etag and size of the FA and not the whole object,
so we need to use the container override header to store
the object's value in the container database.

Change-Id: I12dea597889b1227bddeda995f703346bc2be7e1
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/30/161030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'X-Backend-Container-Update-Override-Etag': client_obj_hasher.hexdigest(), 'X-Backend-Container-Update-Override-Size':

commit_message:
Ensure that external secret refs cannot be added to containers

Prior to this change, it was possible for one to point secret_refs to
arbitrary locations, especially in the context of adding secrets to a
container given that the hostname part of the secret_ref was being
ignored. Since we are now checking secret_refs against the
configured hostname of the Barbican instance, this is no longer
possible. In other words, this is just some extra validation to ensure
that parameters remain consistent with the Barbican instance
configuration.
Closes-Bug: 1423282

Change-Id: Ife1d66f234050e3150a879e76142b68f8f72a524
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/17/161417/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_ensure_unconfigured_secret_ref_hostname_cannot_be_passed_in(self): # Here goes some bogus secret refs. secret_refs = [ { 'name': 'super-secret-beer-ingredient', 'secret_ref': 'http://kegeratorsarecool.com:9311/1234/secrets/57890' }, { 'name': 'iShouldNotBeAbleToExist', 'secret_ref': 'http://completely.invalid.fqdn:9311/v1/secrets/FAD23' } ] container_req = { 'name': 'test-container', 'type': 'generic', 'secret_refs': secret_refs } exception = self.assertRaises(excep.SecretRefValidationErrorException, self.validator.validate, container_req, )

commit_message:
export OS_* variables even if keystone is not installed

   OS_* variables are not exported if keystone is not installed in
   some nodes, which causes network/compute node installation
   failure. The fix is to export OS_* creds variables even if
   keystone is not installed in network/computer node

Change-Id: I801d181b95a98a46e72cd70fcfaee587db4970a9
Closes-Bug: #1427086
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/97/161597/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set up a temporary admin URI for Keystone SERVICE_ENDPOINT=$KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI/v2.0# Set up password-flow auth creds export OS_AUTH_URL=$SERVICE_ENDPOINT export OS_TENANT_NAME=admin export OS_USERNAME=admin export OS_PASSWORD=$ADMIN_PASSWORD export OS_REGION_NAME=$REGION_NAME
deleted_lines: # Set up a temporary admin URI for Keystone SERVICE_ENDPOINT=$KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI/v2.0 # Set up password-flow auth creds now that keystone is bootstrapped export OS_AUTH_URL=$SERVICE_ENDPOINT export OS_TENANT_NAME=admin export OS_USERNAME=admin export OS_PASSWORD=$ADMIN_PASSWORD export OS_REGION_NAME=$REGION_NAME

commit_message:
OS_* variables are not exported if keystone is not installed in
   some nodes, which causes network/compute node installation
   failure. The fix is to export OS_* creds variables even if
   keystone is not installed in network/computer node

Change-Id: I14eecf06d4e2ecea6d39cd676092d35ee8e5f8a7
Closes-Bug: #1427086
Author: Ruijing Guo <ruijing.guo@intel.com>

commit_message:
Move Neutron Policy pages into the tree

The information from the NeutronPolicies wiki page [1] is useful. But
having it in a static wiki is less so. Moving this into the Neutron
documentation in-tree will allow for an easier maintenance of this
information.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NeutronPolicies

Change-Id: I23cada04031e00f48c0f6dc26a992ed204195526
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/99/161799/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Core Neutron Reviewers ====================== The `Neutron Core Reviewer Team <https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/38,members>`_ is responsible for merging changes into the following repositories: * `openstack/neutron <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron/>`_ * `openstack/neutron-fwaas <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-fwaas/>`_ * `openstack/neutron-lbaas <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-lbaas/>`_ * `openstack/neutron-vpnaas <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/>`_ * `openstack/python-neutronclient <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/python-neutronclient/>`_ * `openstack/neutron-specs <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-specs/>`_ While eveyrone is encouraged to review changes for these repositories, members of the neutron-core gerrit group have the ability to +2/-2 and +A changes these repositories. This is responsibility that is not to be taken lightly. Adding or Removing Core Reviewers --------------------------------- A new Neutron core reviewer may be proposed at anytime on the openstack-dev mailing list. Typically, the Neutron PTL will propose a new member after discussions with the existing core reviewers. Once a proposal has been made, five existing Neutron core reviewers must respond to the email with a +1. Another Neutron core reviewer can vote -1 to veto the proposed new core reviewer. The PTL may remove a Neutron core reviewer at any time. Typically when a member has decreased their involvment with the project through a drop in reviews and participation in general project development, the PTL will propose their removal and remove them. Please note there is no voting or vetoing of core reviewer removal. Members who have previously been a core reviewer may be fast-tracked back into a core reviewer role if their involvment picks back up and the existing core reviewers support their re-instatement. Core Reviewer Membership Expectations ------------------------------------- Neutron core reviewers have the following expectations: * Resonable attendance at the weekly Neutron IRC meetings. * Participation in Neutron discussions on the mailing list, as well as in-channel in #openstack-neutron. * Particiaption in Neutron related design summit sessions at the OpenStack Summits. In addition to the above, code reviews are the most important requirement of Neutron core reviewers. Neutron follows the documented OpenStack `code review guidelines <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ReviewChecklist>`_. We encourage all people to review Neutron patches, but core reviewers are required to maintain a level of review numbers relatively close to other core reviewers. There are no hard statistics around code review numbers, but in general we use 30, 60, 90 and 180 day stats when examing review stats. * `30 day review stats <http://stackalytics.com/report/contribution/neutron-group/30>`_ * `60 day review stats <http://stackalytics.com/report/contribution/neutron-group/60>`_ * `90 day review stats <http://stackalytics.com/report/contribution/neutron-group/90>`_ * `180 day review stats <http://stackalytics.com/report/contribution/neutron-group/180>`_ There are soft-touch items around being a Neutron core reviewer as well. Gaining trust with the existing Neutron core reviewers is important. Being able to work together with the existing Neutron core review team is critical as well. Being a Neutron core reviewer means spending a significant amount of time with the existing Neutron core reviewer team on IRC, the mailing list, at Summits, and in reviews. Ensuring you participate and engage here is critical to becoming and remaining a core.

subject: Add flat network gateway to br-vlan for AIO builds
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-05 18:28:17.000000000', 'files': ['etc/network/interfaces.d/aio_interfaces.cfg'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/7fe90a849ee10d1254ad11eb875bf9b1cfe21c6f', 'message': 'Add flat network gateway to br-vlan for AIO builds

When an AIO is built using the included scripts and networking config,
the public network has a gateway IP of 172.29.248.1 from the
172.29.248.0/22 network, which is not expected or configured to exist
anywhere. This can cause issues when using floats or in general if
some communication is desired which uses the public side gateway of
the neutron-routed network.

A simple solution is to simply drop 172.29.248.1/22 on br-vlan via the
interface config, which allows the traffic to do the needful, at least
as far as tempest's requirements are concerned. In modern
Debian/Ubuntu, this can be accomplished with another "iface" stanza
with its own "address" directive to add the additional address.

Conflicts:
	etc/network/interfaces.d/aio_interfaces.cfg

Change-Id: I79897bc4e4d7eb7d55ad3c12f55a339dfef869e1
Closes-Bug: #1425717
Related-Bug: #1425255
(cherry picked from commit 0737a6062c2e1c96706bd0289c652dc3802802c2)
'}]
commit_message:
Add flat network gateway to br-vlan for AIO builds

When an AIO is built using the included scripts and networking config,
the public network has a gateway IP of 172.29.248.1 from the
172.29.248.0/22 network, which is not expected or configured to exist
anywhere. This can cause issues when using floats or in general if
some communication is desired which uses the public side gateway of
the neutron-routed network.

A simple solution is to simply drop 172.29.248.1/22 on br-vlan via the
interface config, which allows the traffic to do the needful, at least
as far as tempest's requirements are concerned. In modern
Debian/Ubuntu, this can be accomplished with another "iface" stanza
with its own "address" directive to add the additional address.

Conflicts:
	etc/network/interfaces.d/aio_interfaces.cfg

Change-Id: I79897bc4e4d7eb7d55ad3c12f55a339dfef869e1
Closes-Bug: #1425717
Related-Bug: #1425255
(cherry picked from commit 0737a6062c2e1c96706bd0289c652dc3802802c2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/24/161824/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Add an additional address to br-vlan iface br-vlan inet static # Flat network default gateway # -- This needs to exist somewhere for network reachability # -- from the router namespace for floating IP paths. # -- Putting this here is primarily for tempest to work. address 172.29.248.1 netmask 255.255.252.0

commit_message:
[Sahara] cleanup clusters correctly

Cleaning up clusters w/o waiting until a cluster is completely removed
may cause different side-effects. For example floating ips may leave
allocated to a tenant which then is deleted by other clean ups. The ips
the cannot be removed. The same applies to security groups.

Change-Id: I8c82d2a6aad2398aa48f34285a6e0ab61c6bc1fe

commit_message:
Add support of bay resource management with "name"

This patch supports magnum bay resource related
commands to run with name of the resource also.
Below is the list of commands:
 - bay-show
 - bay-delete

Depends on I5e5b849aac4929237d50eac2a2e889c9f94be945
Partially implements blueprint name-based-resource-management

Change-Id: I3b751b3a2b9e35d913008f383db52544440e5075

commit_message:
Prevent update of ReadOnlyDict

This must have seemed like a good idea at the time. Let's get rid of it
before it trips someone up.

Change-Id: I6971cfd60ec17b670a96350ca4869e87abf3735b

commit_message:
Exposes bug in SQL/LDAP when honoring driver_hints

SQL and LDAP backends fails to honor multiple
valued driver_hints due to a wrong manipulation
of the list of filters.

This patch exposes this bug.

Related-Bug: #1424745

Change-Id: I505cb5e1e9e63a2c93a1fda9f81f8d188e09c233

added_lines: from keystone.tests.unit import utils @utils.wip('Exposes bug #1424745') def test_multiple_valued_filters(self): """GET /domains?enabled=0&id=<domainA.id> Test Plan: - Update policy for no protection on api - Filter by the 'enabled=0' boolean and name - this should return no domain, since domainA is enabled """ new_policy = {"identity:list_domains": []} self._set_policy(new_policy) url = '/domains?enabled=0&id=%s' % self.domainA['id'] r = self.get(url, auth=self.auth) # Since domainA is enabled, the response should be an empty list self.assertEqual([], r.result.get('domains'))

commit_message:
create noauth2

This creates a noauth2 auth_strategy which is similar to noauth,
except it only gives you an admin context if the username passed in is
'admin'. This allows testing of non admin activities.

noauth is deprecated as of this commit. While we expect that it would
only be used in testing, it is exposed as a conf option, so could be
used behind a different auth proxy.

Also make the error path for pipeline loading contain a full
LOG.exception. This is a fatal condition for nova, and the current
error was often quite opaque. The full stack trace during this fatal
error makes addressing paste.ini issues much more straight forward.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I7cb5ab3e43a1e3bd7ccba0480053361743f859b2

commit_message:
enhance flavor manage functional tests

Enhance the flavor manage functional tests to nearly cover what's done
in the equivalent Tempest tests (especially the negative
tests). Specifically we add tests for deleted flavor handling, and
bounds checking of various parameters.

The remaining missing negative tests are related to authorization
testing, which requires more changes to the OSAPIFixture
infrastructure.

Change-Id: I53a9343e582650ca0e238be2dc3d9d7f5f87b9c8

commit_message:
Add API Response class for more complex testing

the api client .api_(get|delete|post|put) do useful encoding/decoding
of the request/response from dictionaries, and to dictionaries. For
negative and functional testing we're going to often need the status
code as well.

This creates an APIResponse class which wraps and decodes the Requests
library response that is returned. That provides easy access to the
decoded json, as well as access to things like status code and
headers.

It's used in follow on tests to make them more concise.

The convenience methods in the test client (such as get_server) are
adapted to return the same information as before, but through this new
method. These will be further documented in future commits.

Change-Id: I692cbc1a39c3802799de45b4c40306fd717feabf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/159268/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class OpenStackAPIResponse(dict): """Dictionary wrapper for API responses This class is a simple wrapper around dictionaries for API responses in tests. It includes extra attributes so that they can be inspected in addition to the attributes. All json responses from Nova APIs are dictionary compatible, or blank, so other possible base classes are not needed. """ status_code = 200 """The HTTP status code as an int""" def __str__(self): # because __str__ falls back to __repr__ we can still use repr # on self but add in the other attributes. return "<Response body:%r, status_code:%s>" % (self, self.status_code) newbody = OpenStackAPIResponse() newbody.status_code = response.status_code if body: newbody.update(jsonutils.loads(body)) return newbody
deleted_lines: if body: return jsonutils.loads(body) else: return ""

commit_message:
Add extended attributes to extended-status extension and bump micro-version

This patch just demo to show how to bump micro-version for extended attributes
and how to write api sample for it.

commit_message:
Add more log info around 'not found' error

Currently log message on nova api does not
have enough info to debug this problem.

Now, with this patch we included more log
messages to print more info.

Change-Id: I73d80500ebbbe3f896658037e104be15024658ec
Closes-Bug: #1278849

'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2015-02-24 13:08:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/cb2ef36bd86e11f05c0cdd816abf49f36c5e11f8', 'message': 'Add extra data to Stack table for Convergence.

The convergence design requires extra data to be stored with each Stack
row in order to manage concurrent updates.

Stack updates will be atomic and UPDATE...WHERE clause is used within a
transaction to ensure atomicity. current_traversal column of stack table
is used for atomicity. Consumers of stack update API will have to pass
the current_traversal that they know of (from the previous stack fetch)
to update the values in DB. Meanwhile, if any other thread/process
updates the current_traversal, then ConcurrentStackUpdate exception is
raised.

In the update query for updating the stack, session synchronization
is set to False to avoid error causing due to status_reason column
inherited in Stack table from the StateAware table. Updates to
status_reason column is handled via @property and this causes problems
due to the fact that the UPDATE...WHERE updates it in DB but fails to
correctly evaluate the sqlalchemy object directly. The evaluation fails
with "KeyError" on status_reason column. By setting synchronization off
and by expiring the session, we enforce status_reason to be read from DB
again.

Change-Id: I5f7482b94d76d937f03772596873c46bd536ac4f
Implements: blueprint convergence-stack-data

commit_message:
Add extra data to Stack table for Convergence.

The convergence design requires extra data to be stored with each Stack
row in order to manage concurrent updates.

In the update query for updating the stack, session synchronization
is set to False to avoid error causing due to status_reason column
inherited in Stack table from the StateAware table. Updates to
status_reason column is handled via @property and this causes problems
due to the fact that the UPDATE...WHERE updates it in DB but fails to
correctly evaluate the sqlalchemy object directly. The evaluation fails
with "KeyError" on status_reason column. By setting synchronization off
and by expiring the session, we enforce status_reason to be read from DB
again.

Implements: blueprint convergence-stack-data

Change-Id: I5f7482b94d76d937f03772596873c46bd536ac4f

commit_message:
Adds filtering for BONDING (LACP)

- Separated ifcfg file capture from cleaning filter
- Fixed REGEX when ifcfg file used as template

RHBZ#1165185

Change-Id: I26d53c832e651668b40a70010bb994e5d2ec10da
(cherry picked from commit fd49af3de8ab156e9680d42b6309c79d4e68e9cb)

commit_message:
Add document mapping Neutron to ovn-nb db

This covers enough to work on the implementation of the L2 part.  Some
of the L3 aspects still need to be worked out.

Change-Id: I064298eadde391b93deda6c608a0a6c1ee3b69c5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/52/160052/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Mapping between Neutron and OVN data models ======================================================== The primary job of the OVN ML2 mechanism driver is to translate requests for resources into OVN's data model. Resources are created in OVN by updating the appropriate tables in the OVN northbound database (an ovsdb database). This document looks at the mappings between the data that exists in Neutron and what the resulting entries in the OVN northbound DB would look like. Network ---------- Neutron Network: id name subnets admin_state_up status tenant_id Once a network is created, we should create an entry in the Logical Switch table. OVN northbound DB Logical Switch: external_ids: { 'neutron:network_id': network.id, 'neutron:network_name': network.name } Subnet --------- Neutron Subnet: id name ip_version network_id cidr gateway_ip allocation_poos dns_nameservers host_routers tenant_id enable_dhcp ipv6_ra_mode ipv6_address_mode ... Port ------- Neutron Port: id name network_id admin_state_up mac_address fixed_ips device_id device_owner tenant_id status When a port is created, we should create an entry in the Logical Switch Ports table in the OVN northbound DB. OVN Northbound DB Logical Switch Port: switch: reference to OVN Logical Switch router_port: (empty) name: port.id up: (read-only) macs: [port.mac_address] port_security: external_ids: {'neutron:port_name': port.name} Router ---------- ... OVN Northbound DB Logical Router: ip: default_gw: external_ids:

commit_message:
REST Angular for Cinder Fix

The REST API for angular had two small issues that were fixed
in a larger patch.  Pulling that fix out to here to reduce
the side of the larger patch.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/158929/11/

Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign

Change-Id: I267fa78c37593d59bb12e12298da350ee6253908

commit_message:
Correct the check_update_completion logic in instance_group

The automated resource update logic is incompatible with the up coming
logic in decouple-nested, as it doesn't poll the check_update_complete
correctly.

Change-Id: I9c3d1f314ce7da3abda391ff2e0ab05d6c1d76ae
Closes-bug: #1360292

commit_message:
skip rerunning requirements changes in devstack

Requirements changes to projects trigger tempest/grenade
jobs. However, these are exactly the same tests as would have just
been run in the requirements job before we propose requirements
changes to projects. So the merge of a requirements change current
creates a great thundering herd in all the projects.

Skip if this is the proposal bot and the only content changed is
requirements. The requirements check job will ensure that people can't
sneak an invalid requirement range in.

Change-Id: Ie0c7470eae497ec666f200d2119f5de415901d1b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/14/156214/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # because of global requirements overrides, there is no reason to # run tempest/grenade tests after a requirements sync, as they've # already been run in the requirements job with the override. - name: ^.*(tempest|grenade)-dsvm.*$ skip-if: - project: ^openstack/ all-files-match-any: - ^(test-|)requirements.txt$

commit_message:
Set the request_spec with the value of the new type in migration

So far, the request_spec value is still set with the old type name in
volume migration, which will lead to error of no host is found. This
is something we need to fix.

closes-bug: #1421147

Change-Id: I1329bc5bee548ee452bb267feab679a087a2ea90

commit_message:
Adds x509 certificate keypair support

X509 certificates are used by Windows for passwordless
authentication (WinRM) in a way which can be considered
consistent with the usage of SSH keys on Linux, as both
are based on public / private keypairs.

Adds x509 certificate creation implementation.
Adds 'keys' in InstanceMetadata.

Implements: blueprint keypair-x509-certificates

Depends-On: Id5b210d7afe5c0a590abcbd42b9ff85b071a5c55

Change-Id: I1ab518553cf757ae35548fa89b6c8fee7ec32b8d

This makes the next patch in the series cleaner.

pt2) def test_numa_pages_not_equivalent(self): pt1 = objects.NUMAPagesTopology(size_kb=1024, total=32, used=0) pt2 = objects.NUMAPagesTopology(size_kb=1024, total=33, used=0) self.assertNotEqual(pt1, siblings=[set([5, 6])]) self.assertNotEqual(cell1, cell2) def test_numa_cell_not_equivalent_missing_a(self): cell1 = objects.NUMACell(id=1, cpuset=set([1, 2]), memory=32, pinned_cpus=set([3, 4]), siblings=[set([5, 6])]) cell2 = objects.NUMACell(id=2, cpuset=set([1, 2]), memory=32, cpu_usage=10, pinned_cpus=set([3, 4]), siblings=[set([5, 6])]) self.assertNotEqual(cell1, cell2) def objects.NUMAPagesTopology(size_kb=1024, total=32, used=1) cell1 = objects.NUMACell(id=1, cpuset=set([1, 2]), memory=32, cpu_usage=10, pinned_cpus=set([3, 4]), siblings=[set([5, 6])], mempages=[pt1]) cell2 = objects.NUMACell(id=1, cpuset=set([1, 2]), memory=32, cpu_usage=10, pinned_cpus=set([3, 4]), siblings=[set([5, 6])], mempages=[pt2]) self.assertNotEqual(cell1, cell2)

commit_message:
Create extension provider instances once

The provider instance for the extensions (federation and oauth1) were
created multiple times when keystone-all was run because there's one
instance created per pipeline (once for "admin" and once for "public").
The dependency module is enhanced to provide a function to create the
instance of a provider only if it hasn't been created already and the
extensions changed to use it rather than create the manager directly.

Change-Id: I0077f776284b2efe0e575a692203140012b16747
Partial-Bug: 1408384

commit_message:
Fix swiftclient func tests to run using both auth versions

The rationale for this change is the same as for merged change
to swift func tests job [1].

The swiftclient functional test job was changed to run
tox -e func as sudo [2]. The job first runs functional tests
against keystone, then repeats the tests against tempauth.
The second part of the job requires SWIFT_TEST_CONFIG_FILE
env var to be set to cause the tests to run against tempauth.
The introduction of sudo in [2] causes this env var to be lost,
so the tests run against keystoneauth again.

[1] change id Ibea153e94e7919b5422a344d365cee3106efb2fe
[2] change id Ifc3e862b0fe86928c3943a41f07cd086d6ace6fe

Change-Id: Ieea3efbd6526edb8038b677a2e2278107acfe211
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/44/160844/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Change metadata driver unit tests to use monitored spawn

The modified unit test is currently the sole user of the
unmonitored _spawn_metadata_proxy. We must remove this usage so that
when the L3 agent manages the metadata proxy for HA routers,
the unmanaged methods may be removed.

Related-Bug: #1402010
Change-Id: Ib57e63dcadc378ac51702949ed24901d403002dd

commit_message:
Add python26 jobs to debtcollector

Since the debtcollector library is used by
oslo libraries (which still support 2.6 for the
time being) so should this library (which it
already should support) until we can finally
drop 2.6 support from the using libraries.

Change-Id: Ie744544004fcc35a892788a231c1e7408106d903
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/28/160928/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use bind-mounted directory for tempest logs

In an effort to improve the artifacts we have from the gate, make
tempest record its logs in the utility container's bind-mounted log
directory. The gate publisher will then automatically copy the file.

Conflicts:
	rpc_deployment/roles/tempest/templates/tempest.conf.j2

Related-bug: 1425482
Change-Id: I5811c2d34772ef4711d9c483038edb5a5c1a6897
(cherry picked from commit 1f09957c23dd6e11b15648a9eec873b0fa925f6e)

added_lines: log_file = /var/log/utility/tempest.log

commit_message:
zuul-swift-upload support recursive globs

Allow supplying filename and paths with '**' recursive glob matches
to zuul-swift-upload. Since bash (or shell etc) will expand on any
filenames provided to the program this needs to be used in quotes.

Usage example:
./zuul_swift_upload.py my_results.txt '**/sdist/*.zip' output.log

The hierarchy is always flattened meaning the supplied list is
placed in the topmost generated index.html. Sub-folders still keep
their hierarchy.

Change-Id: I9ba04f7e46b579dcf3f8ad0bd188f41fa5dbcad9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/14/158514/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Authough it is not required, but we use self for member method and
cls for class method generally.

commit_message:
Config driver: update help text for force_config_drive

The supported values are 'always', 'True' and 'False'. Update the
help text to support this.

DocImpact

UpgradeImpact

NOTE: the 'always' option will be deprecated in Liberty.

Change-Id: Ib3de8402addb4657f4f6ede35792aab0b1498ff8
Partial-bug: #1403889

commit_message:
Rest API for Users list filter

Add the filter functionality that Keystone supports.
Used by Randy's Magic Search patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/151386/.

Also refactor out parse_filters_kwargs method which is used
by several rest api.

Co-Authored-By: Justin Pomeroy <jpomero@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

Change-Id: Ib65395eae345e1368fbb45f6b4ce3cbb9595d61b
Partially-Implements: blueprint filtered-client-side-table

commit_message:
Move _set_subnet_arp_info to dvr_router

Further teasing DVR apart from the agent and other router types.  This
change illustrates the need to use plugin_rpc and context from the
agent.  It leaves this as a dependence of dvr_router on the instance
of the agent.  So, when the agent creates a dvr_router, it passes
itself in as an argument.  It doesn't do this with other router types.

I would like to eliminate the dependence of RPC while processing a
router.  However, this is just a refactor and at least decouples it as
much as possible and isolates the dependence to DVR only.

Change-Id: Icb2154648b7aee6ddf781c48f1801ff97d35c6e6
Partially-Implements: bp/restructure-l3-agent
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/60/158460/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_ports_by_subnet(self, subnet_id): return self.plugin_rpc.get_ports_by_subnet(self.context, subnet_id)
deleted_lines: def _set_subnet_arp_info(self, ri, port): """Set ARP info retrieved from Plugin for existing ports.""" if 'id' not in port['subnet'] or not ri.router['distributed']: return subnet_id = port['subnet']['id'] subnet_ports = ( self.plugin_rpc.get_ports_by_subnet(self.context, subnet_id)) for p in subnet_ports: if p['device_owner'] not in l3_constants.ROUTER_INTERFACE_OWNERS: for fixed_ip in p['fixed_ips']: ri._update_arp_entry(fixed_ip['ip_address'], p['mac_address'], subnet_id, 'add')

subject: Add info for Standalone EC2 API to cut access to Nova DB.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-13 18:26:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c91ae0cda04b20fd142a5433bfad580dd1d1428f', 'message': 'Add info for Standalone EC2 API to cut access to Nova DB.

This change adds properties to v2.1 and v3
os-extended-server-properties nova APIs in order to expose information
which is required for the standalone EC2 API implementation
(resides on stackforge/ec2-api) to use only public APIs. Right now
this information is taken by directly accessing internal Nova DB.
It implements the spec "Nova changes required for standalone EC2 API
implementation" in this review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153636/

APIImpact
Implements: blueprint ec2-api

Change-Id: I850e51e730c82906f68fddb14fb0004d7091eb91

commit_message:
Add info for Standalone EC2 API to cut access to Nova DB.

This change adds properties to v2.1
os-extended-server-properties and os-extended-volumes nova APIs
in order to expose information which is required for the standalone
EC2 API implementation (resides on stackforge/ec2-api) to use only
public APIs. Right now this information is taken by directly accessing
internal Nova DB.
It adds proposed microversion v2.3.
It implements the spec "Nova changes required for standalone EC2 API
implementation" in this review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153636/

APIImpact
Implements: blueprint ec2-api

Change-Id: I850e51e730c82906f68fddb14fb0004d7091eb91

commit_message:
Add ability to run pylint check on modified files only

Change c0aa0b fused pylint with the checks done with the pep8 testenv.
This has the drawback of increasing the execution time of the command
'tox -epep8' fourfold.

This change introduces the ability to execute the pylint check on just
the list of python files affected by a specific patch. For instance,
this can be done with the following command:

   tox -epep8 HEAD~1

A kind reminder is added, so that folks who end up noticing the spike of
time execution when they run tox -epep8 without posargs, can learn how
they can get their precious minutes back.

Change-Id: Ie2a2b3a0171908d8d8aa8713baaa875adccb7efe

commit_message:
Align cert, key, cacert and verify with requests

The semantics of these values are specific, and an interface we'd
carried over from the old ansible modules really just makes things more
confusing.

Requests expects that verify can either be True/False or can be the path
to a cacert bundle. That makes it very hard to do input parameter
validation in ansible. So - split that into verify which takes a boolean
and a path to a cacert bundle.

Requests also expects that cert can either be a path to a cert/key
bundle, or a tuple of two paths. I'm not really sure why it thinks
that's clever, but I don't.

Change-Id: Ie96e7afe3ef056499477b746d9262975081206d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/83/160183/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Represent a connection to an OpenStack Cloud. OpenStackCloud is the entry point for all cloud operations, regardless of which OpenStack service those operations may ultimately come from. The operations on an OpenStackCloud are resource oriented rather than REST API operation oriented. For instance, one will request a Floating IP and that Floating IP will be actualized either via neutron or via nova depending on how this particular cloud has decided to arrange itself. :param cloud: A Cloud Configuration object, obtained from os-client-config :type cloud: :py:class:`os_client_config.config.OpenStackConfig` :param string region: The region of the cloud that all operations should be performed against. :param string auth_plugin: The name of the keystone auth_plugin to be used :param bool verify: The verification arguments to pass to requests. True tells requests to verify SSL requests, False to not verify. (optional, defaults to True) :param string cacert: A path to a CA Cert bundle that can be used as part of verifying SSL requests. If this is set, verify is set to True. (optional) :param string cert: A path to a client certificate to pass to requests. (optional) :param string key: A path to a client key to pass to requests. (optional) :param bool debug: Enable or disable debug logging (optional, defaults to False) :param int cache_interval: How long to cache items fetched from the cloud. Value will be passed to dogpile.cache. None means to just use the default in dogpile.cache. (optional, defaults to None) """ verify=True, cacert=None, cert=None, key=None, if cacert: if not os.path.exists(cacert): raise OpenStackCloudException( "CA Cert {0} does not exist".format(cacert)) verify = cacert if cert: if not os.path.exists(cert): raise OpenStackCloudException( "Client Cert {0} does not exist".format(cert)) if key: if not os.path.exists(key): raise OpenStackCloudException( "Client key {0} does not exist".format(key)) cert = (cert, key)
deleted_lines: insecure=False, verify=None, cacert=None, cert=None, key=None, if verify is None: if insecure: verify = False else: verify = cacert or True if cert and key: cert = (cert, key)

commit_message:
Allow changing base image

By changing the PREFIX variable in the .buildconf one is now able to
build docker images from different bases.

For example, add the following line to your .buildconf file to build
CentOS based images:

    PREFIX=centos-rdo-

Default base image is Fedora. For now only RH family is supported.

Additionally, changing the namespace either with the NAMESPACE variable
in .buildconf or via --namespace commandline option now changes the
source namespace as well from the default kollaglue one.

Implements: blueprint multi-baseos
Co-Authored-By: Steven Dake <stdake@cisco.com>

commit_message:
Task Flow integration with volume driver

The volume driver framework provides an abstraction point for
integrating external storage of varying types to virtual machines.

This change set links up the volume driver framework with the overall
compute driver.

Provides the following:
 - Create a volume driver mapping framework.  To enable future volume
   types.
 - Task Flow integration for connecting and disconnecting volumes.
 - Renames some of the remaining task flow classes for clarity
 - Provides a base vscsi volume driver.  No implementation (will be
   another change set).

Change-Id: Ie8d2aabd13c16ee19a09d8b7fbee03fb5b218ee7

""" def connect_volume(self, connection_info, disk_dev): """Connects the volume.""" pass def disconnect_volume(self, connection_info, disk_dev): """Disconnect the volume.""" pass

commit_message:
Containerize OpenStack services via TripleO

Proposes containerizing OpenStack deployments via TripleO by using a library
built in Kolla or some other location to abstract the upgrade, downgrade &
deployment process.  By abstracting the process, the use of containers
can be introduced optionally with minimal impact.

Change-Id: I70fbd00b4939dfbed150624f69698b4af4b4f21c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/99/144199/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================== Containerize Tripleo ==================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/containerize-tripleo Containerizing TripleO offers significant advantages and value for OpenStack deployers. By using containers, it is possible to have automatic high availability and automatic deployment of the OpenStack deployed services by simply starting and starting the container. Big advantages are added around configuration management as well. Since containers are immutable, they offer a nicely improved image management model. OpenStack vendors can place their latest images as well as any older versions in a Docker repo for full upgrade and downgrade to any version the OpenStack vendors make available. The dependency we prefer to use for this model is an OS image that contains docker and kubernetes. Kubernetes will run a check script on a configurable interval. If it returns an error, the container will be restarted. This is how high availability is automated without a bunch of extra complication. When a deployer wishes to upgrade her cloud, she simply requests tripleo to redeploy one of the services. This executes library calls in the proposed blueprint which stop and start the impacted services with minimal downtime. The configuration management that is handled by puppet can either be reused in this model or refactored to store key/value pairs in the tripleo configuration system. With the later model, configuration management doesn't require any configuration management dependency. All of the configuration managemnt is handled by tripleO and as key-value pairs sent to the container on start. A configuration change stops and starts the impacted service which reconfigures the service based upon the latest images. Problem Description =================== Use cases: * Reconfigure a service without redploying the entire node or involving a third party CM dependency. * High availability without configuring a third party dependency such as The Linux high availability stack Pacemaker + Corosync. * Very high availability upgrades without redploying the entire node, but instead just redeploying the impacted containers on an already deployed Ironic node. Proposed Change =============== First the kolla core will develop a library for TripleO to use. Where this library lives is up to the reviewers. Some options include the kolla stackforge repo, oslo, or somewhere else in tripelo. The library will deploy either Fedora Atomic, RHEL Atomic, or CoreOS. These operating systems support Docker + Kubernetes out of the box. For those deploying Ubuntu, we suspect Ubuntu Snappy will eventually provide similar functionality we require as based on the other reference operating systems. Once deployed, the library will manage upgrade and downgrade of services. The library will be integrated somewhere inside tripleo (hints as to where would be appreciated from the reviewers :) The scope of the effort is only around the development of the library and intregration of the library with TripleO. Alternatives ------------ Another option for container deployment is to depend on a container as a service solution such as Magnum. The blueprint authors believe Magnum will be prime time in L-M cycles before considered for Incubation, so the path is slower. The advantage of this proposal is it wraps the functionality in a library so a CaaS such as Magnum could be used to do the job when it is available. Security Impact --------------- This change involves parsing the key/value configuration pairs, which may include sensistive data such as administrator or other passwords in Keystone. Other End User Impact --------------------- Ideally the user would be shielded from this change via abstraction. There may be some configuration options required, however, which should be set. Performance Impact ------------------ We don't expect much impact on performance since the solution refactors the existing deployment a bit. The usage of kubernetes and docker on the deployed nodes does have a small memory footprint impact. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Config options will be added. It is unclear if the library will require persistent storage, but it may, in which case a database URI must be configured. The change does not take effect unless it is explicitly enabled as part of the deployment process. Developer Impact ---------------- We see minimal impact on developers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sdake@redhat.com Other contributors: kolla-core@review.openstack.org Work Items ---------- * Define top level API of integration with TripelO (2-4 weeks) as a spec likely living in the kolla repo * Implement API (4-6 weeks) likely in kolla repo but open to suggestions * Integrate library into TripleO code base (TODO: where precisely?) Dependencies ============ * Ironic Bare metal service. * A Kubernetes and Docker enabled base operating system deployed via Ironic. * This library by the TripleO code base. Note this library has not been designed or implemented. Testing ======= Should be testable via current CI. Documentation Impact ==================== * The configuration options should be documented. * The advantages and any disadvantages of container deployment should be documented. References ========== None

commit_message:
Add Big Switch Networking library to StackForge

This repository will hold the Big Switch-specific
core plugin, ML2 driver, and service plugins for
Neutron.

This is necessary for the Neutron decomposition
plan defined in [1].

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/134680/

Change-Id: I2935a2785e649f3d4f955729fd209b6dd7457dcb

commit_message:
Introduce config for neutron extended job

This patch adds a new config element to features.yaml for the neutron
extended job, which will run tests for "advanced" services alongside
tests for core functionality.

To this aim a new 'neutron-services' feature is added. Services for
this feature will be loaded only when the neutron-ext config is
requested. As a result, these services won't be loaded anymore when
the 'standard' neutron config is requested.

Change-Id: I6b9c2cf47964ab922a6ad1a81c422a06889c0ca5

commit_message:
Fix ICMP code/type in security group rule test

Security group rule with ICMP protocol has type/code fields which
should follow ICMP specification. Remove the ones that are invalid
and add more meaningful type/code values.
    - Echo Request (type 8, code 0)
    - Echo Response (type 0, code 0)
    - Time Exceeded (type 11, code None)

Change-Id: Ia82193eca71f97581e11badd545ac28236f68f85
Closes-bug: #1425328

commit_message:
Make scheduler client reporting use ComputeNode object

This removes the last use of the legacy conductor api for
compute_node_update().

Change-Id: Ia8042bfd0d1bfbe40364afd6cc9fde08aed05f1b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/159255/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_serialization import jsonutils from nova import objects if 'stats' in updates: # NOTE(danms): This is currently pre-serialized for us, # which we don't want if we're using the object. So, # fix it here, and follow up with removing this when the # RT is converted to proper objects. updates['stats'] = jsonutils.loads(updates['stats']) compute_node = objects.ComputeNode(context=context, id=compute_node_id) compute_node.obj_reset_changes() for k, v in updates.items(): setattr(compute_node, k, v) compute_node.save()
deleted_lines: from nova import conductor def __init__(self): self.conductor_api = conductor.API() self.conductor_api.compute_node_update(context, {'id': compute_node_id}, updates)

commit_message:
Introduce a classification of datastores and strategies

This change introduces a classification of datastores and strategies
based on our understanding of the readiness of that particular item of
code. It reflects the conversation at the mid-cycle in Seattle (Kilo).

A specification for this change was submitted for review in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154119/

Implements: blueprint experimental-datastores
DocImpact
Change-Id: Id710bdd21070c3af160f1594d29c5ac41d5c3548

commit_message:
Two choices for iscsi_helper is missing

In the cinder/volume/driver.py, scstadmin and ietadm were missing from
the choices for iscsi_helper. This will cause SCST and IET target helper
functionality to not work properly.

Change-Id: Ia455e61384d283a47f796466615139361ac9e83e
Closes-Bug: #1428034

commit_message:
Support image conversion during import

Add image conversion during the async import task.

Change-Id: If580faaf913617157d83bca84cffd82b6fff6325
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/92/137992/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================ Image Conversion ================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/basic-import-conversion Basic import conversion of image format With the support of asynchronous operations and the new import workflow in Glance (see the dependency tree), it will possible to have an image format conversion on the fly while importing an image. Problem description =================== Most of the time, user have to convert the image to the expected format manually before creating image in Glance. For example, in Ceph RBD scenario, it only supports raw image. So user have to convert a qcow2 image downloaded from Ubuntu Cloud Archive to raw format by qemu-img. Proposed change =============== The conversion will be provided by a plugin of the import workflow. This plugin can be activated or not based on the deployer configuration. This means that the deployer will need to specify the preferred format of images for the deployment. This blueprint will handle the conversion of formats supported by qemu-img convert: raw, qcow2, vdi, vmdk and vpc. Alternatives ------------ User have to convert the image format manually and who will be blocked until the conversion complete. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- 1. Policy enforcement 2. Necessary image inspection, like image size. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployer need to make sure there is qemu-img installed on controller node. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Fei Long Wang <flwang@catalyst.net.nz> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Core reviewer(s): arnaudleg markwash Other reviewer(s): <launchpad-id or None> <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- * Integrate with taskflow executor * Implement the common image conversion code based on qemu-img * Integrate with default(eventlet) import executor Dependencies ============ * This feature depends on the taskflow executor patch to get a great fit, see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/85211/ It may need some discussions about if the image conversion feature should be supported in default import code (eventlet). Testing ======= Some necessary test cases will be added to test the image conversion code. Documentation Impact ==================== The image REST API document will be updated to indicate the post body change for this feature. Such as the source format and expected format. References ========== [1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-glance-image-conversion

commit_message:
Script to execute CLI cmds to standalone Congress

Added wrapper script "congress_noauth.sh" to execute CLI commands
to standalone congress.
Also updated README with necessary instructions

added_lines: Client for Standalone Congress ------------------------------ To execute CLI commands to standalone congress set with noauth: * Install python-openstackclient:: $ pip install python-openstackclient * Clone repository & install python-congressclient:: $ git clone https://github.com/stackforge/python-congressclient.git $ cd python-congressclient $ python setup.py install * Run script "congress_noauth.sh" to execute CLI commands:: $ cd python-congressclient Edit congress_noauth.sh and fix CONGRESS_URL For example: $ ./congress_noauth.sh policy create test_policy openstack --os-token foo --os-url http://127.0.0.1:1789 congress policy create test_policy +--------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +--------------+--------------------------------------+ | abbreviation | test_ | | description | | | id | 8595f24a-7d74-45ee-8168-0b3e937b8419 | | kind | nonrecursive | | name | test_policy | | owner_id | user | +--------------+--------------------------------------+ $ ./congress_noauth.sh policy rule create test_policy "p(5)" openstack --os-token foo --os-url http://127.0.0.1:1789 congress policy rule create test_policy p(5) +---------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------+--------------------------------------+ | comment | None | | id | 5ce7fb18-a227-447e-bec8-93e99c0052a5 | | name | None | | rule | p(5) | +---------+--------------------------------------+ $ ./congress_noauth.sh policy rule list test_policy openstack --os-token foo --os-url http://127.0.0.1:1789 congress policy rule list test_policy // ID: 5ce7fb18-a227-447e-bec8-93e99c0052a5 // Name: None p(5) * TODO

commit_message:
Decouple L3 and VPN service plugins during router operations

This change leverages the event registry to decouple L3 and VPN
when checking whether certain router operations can be permitted
or not. Patch [1] has the required changes to clean up the Neutron
side.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153776/

Related-blueprint: services-split
Related-blueprint: plugin-interface-perestroika

Change-Id: I6ac366b329466df6c79a3683e6374feca76773a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/93/159793/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.callbacks import events from neutron.callbacks import registry from neutron.callbacks import resources def vpn_callback(resource, event, trigger, params): vpnservice = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( constants.VPN) if vpnservice: context = params.get('context') if resource == resources.ROUTER_GATEWAY: check_func = vpnservice.check_router_in_use resource_id = params.get('router_id') elif resource == resources.ROUTER_INTERFACE: check_func = vpnservice.check_subnet_in_use resource_id = params.get('subnet_id') check_func(context, resource_id) def subscribe(): registry.subscribe( vpn_callback, resources.ROUTER_GATEWAY, events.BEFORE_DELETE) registry.subscribe( vpn_callback, resources.ROUTER_INTERFACE, events.BEFORE_DELETE) # NOTE(armax): multiple VPN service plugins (potentially out of tree) may # inherit from vpn_db and may need the callbacks to be processed. Having an # implicit subscription (through the module import) preserves the existing # behavior, and at the same time it avoids fixing it manually in each and # every vpn plugin in outta there. That said, The subscription is also made # explicitly in the reference vpn plugin. The subscription operation is # idempotent so there is no harm in registering the same callback multiple # times. subscribe()

commit_message:
Use bind-mounted directory for tempest logs

In an effort to improve the artifacts we have from the gate, make
tempest record its logs in the utility container's bind-mounted log
directory. The gate publisher will then automatically copy the file.

Conflicts:
	rpc_deployment/roles/tempest/templates/tempest.conf.j2

Related-bug: 1425482
Change-Id: I5811c2d34772ef4711d9c483038edb5a5c1a6897
(cherry picked from commit 1f09957c23dd6e11b15648a9eec873b0fa925f6e)

commit_message:
Add flat network gateway to br-vlan for AIO builds

When an AIO is built using the included scripts and networking config,
the public network has a gateway IP of 172.29.248.1 from the
172.29.248.0/22 network, which is not expected or configured to exist
anywhere. This can cause issues when using floats or in general if
some communication is desired which uses the public side gateway of
the neutron-routed network.

A simple solution is to simply drop 172.29.248.1/22 on br-vlan via the
interface config, which allows the traffic to do the needful, at least
as far as tempest's requirements are concerned. In modern
Debian/Ubuntu, this can be accomplished with another "iface" stanza
with its own "address" directive to add the additional address.

Conflicts:
	etc/network/interfaces.d/aio_interfaces.cfg

Change-Id: I79897bc4e4d7eb7d55ad3c12f55a339dfef869e1
Closes-Bug: #1425717
Related-Bug: #1425255
(cherry picked from commit 0737a6062c2e1c96706bd0289c652dc3802802c2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/27/161827/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Add an additional address to br-vlan iface br-vlan inet static # Flat network default gateway # -- This needs to exist somewhere for network reachability # -- from the router namespace for floating IP paths. # -- Putting this here is primarily for tempest to work. address 172.29.248.1 netmask 255.255.252.0

subject: devstack/install.sh shouldn't rely on exact paths
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-05 15:16:35.000000000', 'files': ['contrib/devstack/install.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/8ed2b963187815aa07daa0ada91d461728123213', 'message': "devstack/install.sh shouldn't rely on exact paths

Currently the contrib/devstack/install.sh script relies on the fact that
designate and devstack are installed side by side. This isn't always
true and can restrict the developer if he keeps his code someplace else
on the filesystem. This patch proposes a change to install.sh which

commit_message:
devstack/install.sh shouldn't rely on exact paths

Currently the contrib/devstack/install.sh script relies on the fact that
designate and devstack are installed side by side. This isn't always
true and can restrict the developer if he keeps his code someplace else
on the filesystem. This patch proposes a change to install.sh which
stores the pwd (where the script assumes devstack is installed,
according to the installation documentation [1]) and uses that directory
instead.

[1]: https://designate.readthedocs.org/en/latest/devstack.html

Change-Id: I97f7762dde56df6e3b9a45198d9201ec0296d94f
Closes-Bug: 1428679

commit_message:
Updated help on cinder reset-state cli

volumes also have 'in-use', 'attaching' and 'detaching' states.
These were missing in cinder help for reset-state cli. I have added
these in help.

Partial-Bug: #1309086

Change-Id: I094a61dd4921bed83e97134a4bfbcdc7d0c9ad63

added_lines: import re if os.path.exists('/etc/ntp.conf'): server = re.compile('server (.*)') with open('/etc/ntp.conf', 'r') as ntp_config: match = server.search(ntp_config.read()) if match is None: ntp_server = 'pool.ntp.org' else: ntp_server = match.group(1) else: ntp_server = 'pool.ntp.org' config['ntp'] = {'init_config': None, 'instances': [{'host': ntp_server}]}
deleted_lines: import yaml with open(os.path.join(self.template_dir, 'conf.d/ntp.yaml.example'), 'r') as ntp_template: ntp_config = yaml.load(ntp_template.read()) config['ntp'] = ntp_config

subject: Add memcache_servers parameter to base neutron class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-04 22:48:50.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/neutron_init_spec.rb', 'manifests/init.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron/commit/3de594dd8ca3ae39dce29f90a889361a85e70787', 'message': 'Add memcache_servers parameter to base neutron class

commit_message:
Add memcache_servers parameter to base neutron class

Support setting DEFAULT/memcached_servers in neutron.conf through
a new memcache_servers parameter in the base neutron class.

Change-Id: I98fd256661249b80686d74d0c2c2758690e71739
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/58/161458/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [memcache_servers] # List of memcache servers in format of server:port. # Optional. Defaults to false. Example: ['localhost:11211'] # $memcache_servers = false, if $memcache_servers { validate_array($memcache_servers) } if $memcache_servers { neutron_config { 'DEFAULT/memcached_servers': value => join($memcache_servers, ','); } } else { neutron_config { 'DEFAULT/memcached_servers': ensure => absent; } }

commit_message:
Fix jenkins name and floating ip

The jenkins name was accidentally checked in with a test value
and floating ips were not handled correctly.  HPCS was previously
running an older API and I didn't notice until they upgraded
that it was not consistent with devstack.

Change-Id: Ib858726f4ae86ba988bb8c91032b278e08a69c9f

commit_message:
Fix missing parameters for Neutron security group API

1. Query parameters
   Add query parameters for Show/List API.
2. Security Group Rule
   Add some parameters about Security group rule for Show/List/Create API.
3. tenant_id
   Add tenant_id parameter for Show/List/Create API.

Change-Id: Iac9ecf0391a2d4a6713ee337896c2e5ed30607bf
Closes-Bug: #1425337

commit_message:
Spec for VMware Store to use multiple datastores

This spec includes a proposal to support multiple datastores in
the glance VMware store.

Based on blueprint vmware-store-multiple-datastores

Change-Id: I16229da839ab7f147c36d5857e2269999e8215d7

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Glance VMware store to support multiple datastores ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/vmware-store-multiple-datastores Glance, when configured to use VMware store, stores the images in a virtual storage container called datastore, identified by the configuration option vmware_datastore_name. The size of the datastore can only be increased to a certain limit which also depends upon the underlying physical storage. The capacity of the store is thus bound by the size of a single datastore and poses serious scalability issues. Problem description =================== Currently the number of images stored by glance, when configured to use VMware store, is limited by the capacity of a single datastore. The size of a datastore has an upper bound [1]. e.g The maximum datastore size is 64TB when backed by VMFS-5 filesystem. While the same for a datastore with NFS may depend on the storage array vendor. While this is the theoretical maximum based on the supported filesystem, datastores are also sized based on the underlying physical storage, including internal and external devices and networked storage. With networked storage the choice of storage protocol (iSCSI, FC, FCoE) also play a vital role in deciding the optimal size. Thus, the capacity of a datastore used in a datacenter varies by deployment. Apart from the capacity, there may be a performance bottleneck when many compute nodes concurrently access a single datastore to download images. Proposed change =============== To allow adding more capacity and improving performance, we suggest the use of multiple datastores for storing images. There is only one major aspect of the proposed change: - Datastore Selection. **1) Datastore Selection:** This change proposes to select a datastore based on the priority given to it by the operator and the capacity to accommodate the image. A new configuration option (say vmware_datastores) will be added that would enable the operator to specify multiple datastores along with their relative priority. The proposed format is 'datastore_name:priority,'. In case of equal priority the selection will be based on the maximum freespace available on the datastore. This approach is very similar to filesystem_store_datadirs used by filesystem store. Example: say vmware_datastores = 'nfs_datastore:100, iscsi_datastore:100, ssd_datastore: 200'. Here, ssd_datastore will be the preferred datastore if it can accommodate the image being added. Otherwise, nfs_datastore or iscsi_datastore will be chosen based on maximum freespace available. Alternatives ------------ 1) The datastore selection can be done through round-robin/randomized strategy instead of priority-based. This would be ideal if all datastores are of same type and perform similarly. But since datastores are of different types, the strategy is best driven by operator input. e.g SSD backed datastores may be faster that networked datastores. While its possible to determine the type of datastore, implicit assumptions cannot be made. Data model impact ----------------- Does not have any impact on glance data model. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- This spec only adds a selection logic to the existing functionality and hence does not have any security impact. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The use of multiple datastores will reduce concurrent operations on a single datastore. Thus, it will perform better in large deployments. Other deployer impact --------------------- This proposal will allow administrators to configure multiple datastores to save glance image in VMware storage backend. If enabled, it will override the existing configuration option vmware_datastore that allows to specify a single datastore. If disabled, the store will fallback to vmware_datastore option. Thus, the change is backwards compatible. New configuration option in *glance-api.conf* **vmware_datastores** - required Example: vmware_datastores = 'datastore1:100, datastore2:100, datastore3:200' or vmware_datastores = 'datastore1:1' Note: 1. datastore with priority 200 has precedence over datastores with priority 100. 2. If no priority is specified, default priority ‘0’ is associated with it. 3. If two datastores have same priority, datastore with maximum free space will be chosen to store the image. 4. If same datastore is specified multiple times then BadStoreConfiguration exception will be raised. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: smurugesan Other contributors: None Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): TBD Other reviewer(s): None Work Items ---------- 1) Implement new config option in VMware store driver. 2) Implement datastore selection logic in the VMware store driver. 3) Implement unit tests. 4) Change glance-api sample conf in glance repository. Dependencies ============ * May need new utility methods in oslo.vmware. Mostly the proposed change can use existing methods to implement this change. But it may be wise to implement common functionality in oslo.vmware, if any. Testing ======= * Tempest tests are not required. Documentation Impact ==================== * Document new configuration options. References ========== [1] http://www.vmware.com/pdf/vsphere5/r55/vsphere-55-configuration-maximums.pdf

commit_message:
Copy the default value for field

Currently the default value will be used for all instances of the nova
objects. We should return only a copy.

Change-Id: If8e73b92e798cc16cac4952974f5e6210c1bc5e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/11/160611/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copy return self._type.coerce(obj, attr, copy.deepcopy(self._default))

commit_message:
Puppet: First support Ceph

This is a first implementation of Ceph support in TripleO with Puppet:

* Install ceph-mon on controller node
* Install ceph-osd on cephstorage node

Co-Authored-By: Giulio Fidente <gfidente@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I48488cbe950047fae5e746e458106d6edb9a6183

commit_message:
Add oslo.vmware to store requirements

VMware store backend requires oslo.vmware but its not in
requirements. Its currently satisfied by the dependency from
glance project. While the tests are satisfied by the explicit
dependency in test-requirements.

This change adds oslo.vmware to requirements and removes from
test-requirements.

Change-Id: I149cc0b5ccb872cfad24a56bca578fb372a4703e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/79/161879/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: oslo.vmware>=0.11.0 # Apache-2.0

commit_message:
Create _member_ role in keystone bootstrap

The _member_ role must be created because horizon uses this as the default role
to add to users in projects. Unfortunately because we need to add the role id
to the CONF file we have to create this role, insert it into the config file
and then restart keystone to have the change take effect.

This is a similar process as what needs to happen with defining administration
domain_ids for policy so create a function that can be used to bootstrap
keystone with these sort of database/config file synchronized values.

Change-Id: I65738b4f52e750abfc34995e2d618f9b1c57e5b3
Closes-Bug: #1421616
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/90/159690/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bootstrap_keystone

commit_message:
Run cue-api behind Apache2

Change-Id: I2996e5e749e966bae26ab8c914b4a30cc18ec0c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cue refs/changes/14/159614/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Running Cue API behind Apache2 ============================== .. note:: In this howto we explain how to setup cue-api to run behind a Apache2 instance vs as a process of it's own. We will assume that cue is available under /opt/stack/cue as it is in devstack. Symlink app.wsig to /var/www :: $ sudo mkdir /var/www/cue $ sudo ln -s /opt/stack/cue/cue/api/app.wsgi /var/www/cue Setup Apache2 config :: $ sudo cp /opt/cue/etc/apache2/cue.conf /etc/apache2/sites-available $ sudo a2ensite cue $ sudo service apache2 reload You should now have cue-api running under Apache2!

commit_message:
Ensure context is cleared before running context tests

Some other tests call get_admin_context() at import time, which
implicitly registers a context. We should rethink the use of
side-effects like this because it can cause unexpected behavior.
However, this is the easiest short-term workaround.

Change-Id: I5a6e0db04a8c90fe3bb90c21ed4b9d7afb016bdc
Partial-bug: 1428728
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/161800/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FIXME(johannes): Some other tests call get_admin_context() at # import time, which implicitly registers a context. We should # rethink the use of side-effects like this because it can cause # unexpected behavior. However, this is the easiest short-term # workaround. LP1428728 try: del o_context._request_store.context except AttributeError: pass
