subject: Allow disabling the evacuate cleanup mechanism in compute manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-27 15:37:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/86a771eb99365cf02e680474b742eb2a05f1e6d2', 'message': "Allow disabling the evacuate cleanup mechanism in compute manager

This mechanism attempts to destroy any locally-running instances on
startup if instance.host != self.host. The assumption is that the
instance has been evacuated and is safely running elsewhere. This is
a dangerous assumption to make, so this patch adds a configuration
variable to disable this behavior if it's not desired.

Note that disabling it may have implications for the case where
instances *were* evacuated, given potential shared resources.
To counter that problem, this patch also makes _init_instance()
skip initialization of the instance if it appears to be owned
by another host, logging a prominent warning in that case.

As a result, if you have destroy_on_evacuate=False and you start
a nova compute with an incorrect hostname, or run it twice from
another host, then the worst that will happen is you get log
warnings about the instances on the host being ignored. This should
be an indication that something is wrong, but still allow for
fixing it without any loss.

Partial-Bug: #1419785
Change-Id: Ib9a3c72c096822dd5c65c905117ae14994c73e99
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-02-27 16:20:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9580a1c5a9e2331dccd6fdea5696657dd43c3c94', 'message': "Allow disabling the evacuate cleanup mechanism in compute manager

This mechanism attempts to destroy any locally-running instances on
startup if instance.host != self.host. The assumption is that the
instance has been evacuated and is safely running elsewhere. This is
a dangerous assumption to make, so this patch adds a configuration
variable to disable this behavior if it's not desired.

Note that disabling it may have implications for the case where
instances *were* evacuated, given potential shared resources.
To counter that problem, this patch also makes _init_instance()
skip initialization of the instance if it appears to be owned
by another host, logging a prominent warning in that case.

As a result, if you have destroy_after_evacuate=False and you start
a nova compute with an incorrect hostname, or run it twice from
another host, then the worst that will happen is you get log
warnings about the instances on the host being ignored. This should
be an indication that something is wrong, but still allow for
fixing it without any loss. If the configuration option is disabled
and a legitimate evacuation does occur, simply enabling it and then
restarting the compute service will cause the cleanup to occur.

Partial-Bug: #1419785

a dangerous assumption to make, so this patch adds a configuration
variable to disable this behavior if it's not desired.

Note that disabling it may have implications for the case where
instances *were* evacuated, given potential shared resources.
To counter that problem, this patch also makes _init_instance()
skip initialization of the instance if it appears to be owned
by another host, logging a prominent warning in that case.

As a result, if you have destroy_after_evacuate=False and you start
a nova compute with an incorrect hostname, or run it twice from
another host, then the worst that will happen is you get log
warnings about the instances on the host being ignored. This should
be an indication that something is wrong, but still allow for
fixing it without any loss. If the configuration option is disabled
and a legitimate evacuation does occur, simply enabling it and then
restarting the compute service will cause the cleanup to occur.

DocImpact: New configuration option, and peril warning
Partial-Bug: #1419785
Change-Id: Ib9a3c72c096822dd5c65c905117ae14994c73e99

commit_message:
Allow disabling the evacuate cleanup mechanism in compute manager

This mechanism attempts to destroy any locally-running instances on
startup if instance.host != self.host. The assumption is that the
instance has been evacuated and is safely running elsewhere. This is
a dangerous assumption to make, so this patch adds a configuration
variable to disable this behavior if it's not desired.

Note that disabling it may have implications for the case where
instances *were* evacuated, given potential shared resources.
To counter that problem, this patch also makes _init_instance()
skip initialization of the instance if it appears to be owned
by another host, logging a prominent warning in that case.

As a result, if you have destroy_after_evacuate=False and you start
a nova compute with an incorrect hostname, or run it twice from
another host, then the worst that will happen is you get log
warnings about the instances on the host being ignored. This should
be an indication that something is wrong, but still allow for
fixing it without any loss. If the configuration option is disabled
and a legitimate evacuation does occur, simply enabling it and then
restarting the compute service will cause the cleanup to occur.

This is added to the workarounds config group because it is really
only relevant while evacuate is fundamentally broken in this way.
It needs to be refactored to be more robust, and once that is done,
this should be able to go away.

DocImpact: New configuration option, and peril warning
Partial-Bug: #1419785
Change-Id: Ib9a3c72c096822dd5c65c905117ae14994c73e99
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/90/159890/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ' allocation on failures'), cfg.BoolOpt('destroy_after_evacuate', default=True, help='Whether to destroy instances on startup when we suspect ' 'they have previously been evacuated'), if not CONF.destroy_after_evacuate: LOG.warning(_LW('Instance %(uuid)s appears to have been ' 'evacuated from this host to %(host)s. ' 'Not destroying it locally due to ' 'config.'), {'uuid': instance.uuid, 'host': instance.host}) continue # NOTE(danms): If the instance appears to not be owned by this # host, it may have been evacuated away, but skipped by the # evacuation cleanup code due to configuration. Thus, if that # is a possibility, don't touch the instance in any way, but # log the concern. This will help avoid potential issues on # startup due to misconfiguration. if instance.host != self.host: LOG.warning(_LW('Instance %(uuid)s appears to not be owned ' 'by this host, but by %(host)s. Startup ' 'processing is being skipped.'), {'uuid': instance.uuid, 'host': instance.host}) return

commit_message:
Add 'Developer Impact' section for DB Archiving

Specify developers actions for database migrations for shadow tables.

Closes-Bug: #1427402
Related blueprint: db-archiving

Change-Id: I8d49ef3b10c11a917f897e8135670ffe35769748
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/34/160534/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Developers should care about migrations for shadow tables as well, as for original tables: * table creation or deletion requires creating or deleted corresponding shadow tables * when a table is modified, the shadow tables have to get modified * downgrades should be implemented for shadow tables too: new tables have to get removed and the migrated columns will have to get reverted

commit_message:
Add ServerDetail so list can include details

This change falls in line with how Flavor and Image did it, just adding
support for the extended listing of the Server resource.

Change-Id: Ib1675f51c0d7f97b2d5eeced9520142dde52e834
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/98/160598/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list_servers(self, details=True): srv = server.ServerDetail if details else server.Server return srv.list(self.session, paginated=True)

commit_message:
Set Flavor and Image resources on Server

This change sets the resource.prop type for flavor and image to their
respective types of flavor.Flavor and image.Image.

Change-Id: I153ebfa4da9dcde17fa36863ab83917e901f9861
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/18/160618/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack.compute.v2 import flavor from openstack.compute.v2 import image flavor = resource.prop('flavorRef', alias='flavor', type=flavor.Flavor) image = resource.prop('imageRef', alias='image', type=image.Image)
deleted_lines: flavor = resource.prop('flavorRef', alias='flavor', type=dict) image = resource.prop('imageRef', alias='image', type=dict)

subject: Add a stopwatch + split for duration(s)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-10 01:07:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils/commit/b2cbd56316c0e74d953ece91da40637753dc41d7', 'message': "Add a stopwatch + split for duration(s)

The existing timeutils provides a way to measure durations
that is also used to get actual times and dates; for most
cases this dual ability is not needed and the user only cares
about the duration between two time points. In cases where
ntpd may affect the machine clock this usage is also incorrect
and may go backwards in time...

To support this kind of specific and frequently occurring usage
a stopwatch class can be used that can enable more accurate
gathering of *just* durations (and using monotonic time when
it's available in python 3.3+).

The code provides similar override functionality that the rest
of the module provides (its overrides though are part of the
class since the timeutils overrides do not work when monotonic
time is being used).

This code comes from taskflow, but oslo.messaging has similar
code that they could replace with this (and I imagine tooz
could also use this); among others...

Change-Id: I950e26c1eb8283a134fb4f16544f87bc5d29fd82

commit_message:
Add a stopwatch + split for duration(s)

The existing timeutils provides a way to measure durations
that is also used to get actual times and dates; for most
cases this dual ability is not needed and the user only cares
about the duration between two time points. In cases where
ntpd may affect the machine clock this usage is also incorrect
and may go backwards in time...

To support this kind of specific and frequently occurring usage
a stopwatch class can be used that can enable more accurate
gathering of *just* durations (and using monotonic time when
it's available in python 3.3+ or optionally when the library
at http://pypi.python.org/pypi/monotonic is installed).

This code comes from taskflow, but oslo.messaging has similar
code that they could replace with this (and I imagine tooz
could also use this); among others...

Change-Id: I950e26c1eb8283a134fb4f16544f87bc5d29fd82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/11/154311/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class StopWatchTest(test_base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(StopWatchTest, self).setUp() timeutils.StopWatch.set_now_override(now=0) self.addCleanup(timeutils.StopWatch.clear_overrides) def test_leftover_no_duration(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() watch.start() self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.leftover) self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.leftover, return_none=False) self.assertIsNone(watch.leftover(return_none=True)) def test_no_states(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.stop) self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.resume) def test_bad_expiry(self): self.assertRaises(ValueError, timeutils.StopWatch, -1) def test_backwards(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch(0.1) watch.start() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.5) self.assertTrue(watch.expired()) timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(-1.0) self.assertFalse(watch.expired()) self.assertEqual(0.0, watch.elapsed()) def test_expiry(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch(0.1) watch.start() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.2) self.assertTrue(watch.expired()) def test_not_expired(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch(0.1) watch.start() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.05) self.assertFalse(watch.expired()) def test_no_expiry(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch(0.1) self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.expired) def test_elapsed(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() watch.start() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.2) matcher = matchers.GreaterThan(0.19) self.assertThat(watch.elapsed(), matcher) def test_no_elapsed(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.elapsed) def test_no_leftover(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.leftover) watch = timeutils.StopWatch(1) self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, watch.leftover) def test_pause_resume(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() watch.start() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.05) watch.stop() elapsed = watch.elapsed() self.assertAlmostEqual(elapsed, watch.elapsed()) watch.resume() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.05) self.assertNotEqual(elapsed, watch.elapsed()) def test_context_manager(self): with timeutils.StopWatch() as watch: timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.05) matcher = matchers.GreaterThan(0.04) self.assertThat(watch.elapsed(), matcher) def test_splits(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() watch.start() self.assertEqual(0, len(watch.splits)) watch.split() self.assertEqual(1, len(watch.splits)) self.assertEqual(watch.splits[0].elapsed, watch.splits[0].length) timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(0.05) watch.split() splits = watch.splits self.assertEqual(2, len(splits)) self.assertNotEqual(splits[0].elapsed, splits[1].elapsed) self.assertEqual(splits[1].length, splits[1].elapsed - splits[0].elapsed) watch.stop() self.assertEqual(2, len(watch.splits)) watch.start() self.assertEqual(0, len(watch.splits)) def test_elapsed_maximum(self): watch = timeutils.StopWatch() watch.start() timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(1) self.assertEqual(1, watch.elapsed()) timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(10) self.assertEqual(11, watch.elapsed()) self.assertEqual(1, watch.elapsed(maximum=1)) watch.stop() self.assertEqual(11, watch.elapsed()) timeutils.StopWatch.advance_time_seconds(10) self.assertEqual(11, watch.elapsed()) self.assertEqual(0, watch.elapsed(maximum=-1))

commit_message:
Set put_update for compute.v2.server.Server

Updating Servers requires put_update to be set so we use PUT instead of
PATCH.

Change-Id: Ide226d631591b3b528b3f7ea1d335c372f8ead64

Add puppet-lint-param-docs plugins to puppet-lint

commit_message:
Add Puppet 4.x lint checks

- This changes the puppet-lint requirement to 1.1.x, so that we can use
  puppet-lint plugins. Most of these plugins are for 4.x compat, but some just
  catch common errors.

Change-Id: Ie7e1f8b4d4cdd5d058b95cdf2c29c80dc73b954c
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Unindent a chunk of st_list

The chunk looks like nicely containable, but it pushes against the
right edge of the screen annoyingly. This patch _only_ prettifies,
without any observable changes.

Change-Id: I96fcb5848e3e5e0e8a8ebbe398b1d4a0bea5fa24

commit_message:
Fix a minor coding nit in Fernet testing

Before, we were wrapping UUID strings in curly braces. This was because the
Fernet implementation did this when converting uuid.hex strings to bytes. The
implementation has since been refactored to be simpiler. This should follow
suit.

Change-Id: Ie7f35ab2955a4dcc03b8d350224692b65045f70f

commit_message:
Minor change to the service token sample test config

Make the sample test config project for tester5 be test5
to match the configured account in proxy-server.conf-sample.
That way the sample test config will work if uncommented.

commit_message:
Add roles for cookbook openstack-bare-metal

* Adds cookbook-openstack-bare-metal to Berksfile
* Updates infrastructure.yml
* Adds the roles for openstack-bare-metal services
* Adds databag items for openstack-bare-metal

blueprint bare-metal-enablement

Change-Id: Id26509013d33757be65c5f1df6ac11cf33cb6552

commit_message:
Replaces hardcoded volume size by configured value

The volume_create methods used a hardcoded volume_size of 1GB. The
configured volume_size wasn't used on each place. If one used a 
configured image_ref with a volume_size > 1GB this would result in an
error.
This patch replaces all occurrences of the hardcoded volume_size by
the configured value.

Closes-Bug: 1289118
Change-Id: I99cf80e4078eec6a5021793b664b6cfcf02d2988

commit_message:
Catch AttributeError in header with no alias

Now that resource.header is a thing and it's populated with the headers
from a requests.Response, which is a
requests.structures.CaseInsensitiveDict, we have to take an extra step
to make sure we don't try and convert a None-alias to lower case.

Change-Id: I47704191d1822d468389986c5ab203781af59074
Closes-Bug: 1428342

commit_message:
Set int type on several container headers

Several header values for counts and sizes were returning strings.
They are now created with type=int in their respective resource.header.

Change-Id: Ie84343381da6772491a245ae69a07be4477ff3f7

commit_message:
Enables Swift backup driver for auth 2.0

This patch adds support for Swift auth 2.0 to the
 cinder-backup Swift driver.

I've noticed that the changes have been automatically
 made in the following sources:
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/section_cinder.conf.html
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/cinder-conf-changes-juno.html
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/section_volume-misc.html

except for the one in this patch.

Change-Id: If72f718a2757f8f0cd3563bfa8d6bdae4fc81b8b
Closes-Bug: #1355475
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/30/158730/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>The backup driver for Swift back end performs a volume the Swift back end backup driver.</para> <para>To enable Swift backup driver for 1.0 or 2.0 authentication version, specify <literal>1</literal> or <literal>2</literal> correspondingly. For example:</para> <programlisting>backup_swift_auth_version = 1</programlisting> <para>In addition, the 2.0 authentication system requires <parameter>backup_swift_tenant</parameter> setting:</para> <programlisting>backup_swift_tenant = <None></programlisting> backup_swift_auth_version = 1
deleted_lines: <para>The backup driver for Swift back-end performs a volume the Swift back-end backup driver.</para>

Add non-voting tempest dsvm job for Ironic

Add non-voting tempest dsvm job for Ironic project. This job is intended
to test the pxe_* drivers running with the IPA ramdisk.

commit_message:
Reintroduce "Temporarily disable swift-dsvm-functional for Icehouse"

This reverts commit 82de75e83f1efdcb3d4c62648f33b374cfb27576.

The job still fails in gate [1], for different reasons. It also
makes Icehouse broken again. Reverting the revert...

[1]: http://logs.openstack.org/53/157853/3/check/check-swift-dsvm-functional/489975b/console.html

Related-Bug: #1426510
Change-Id: I719029a1a202837ab778eed4f16b552bef6c4417

commit_message:
Flesh out api version defaults

openstackclient needs a bit richer support for api version defaults.
Namely, it knows what defaults it wants to have - but we need to do
defaults processing in os-client-config to get sequencing correct. So
provide an API call to set new defaults that can be used before config
processing. Also, flesh out the dict of known default values with good
defaults to match osc behavior, and add the known v1 default of HP to
the vendors.py values.

Change-Id: I45e2550af58aee616ca168d20a557077beeab007

subject: Rename --verify for server resize to avoid conflict
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-16 03:12:38.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/command-objects/server.rst', 'openstackclient/tests/compute/v2/test_server.py', 'openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/commit/a33f14e298883d6a639b14c9cdb7ac2ba2d0e63d', 'message': 'Rename --verify for server resize to avoid conflict

Currently server resize command has a verify argument for user to
confirm resize operation. But this argument is also registered by
openstack client shell which is used to enable server certificate
verification. So verify argument can not be correctly passed to
server resize command.

This patch renames --verify to --confirm (nova client has a
resize-confirm command) to solve this problem.

Change-Id: I751aa3df16c3b637b82944dd350afc5cbab62120
Closes-Bug: #1416542
'}]
commit_message:
Rename --verify for server resize to avoid conflict

Currently server resize command has a verify argument for user to
confirm resize operation. But this argument is also registered by
openstack client shell which is used to enable server certificate
verification. So verify argument can not be correctly passed to
server resize command.

This patch renames --verify to --confirm (nova client has a
resize-confirm command) to solve this problem.

Change-Id: I751aa3df16c3b637b82944dd350afc5cbab62120
Closes-Bug: #1416542
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/07/156107/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: '--verify', help=_('Verify server resize is complete'), elif parsed_args.verify:

Fix places where role API calls still called assignment_api

There were still a couple of places in our tests where the role
APi calls were going via the stubs in assignment_api. This
patches fixes this.

commit_message:
DHCP should be disabled on external subnet

External network should have dhcp option disabled. But the test
use base create_subnet option which have dhcp enabled by default.
We should pass enable_dhcp=False keyword argument explicitly to
create_subnet for external networks.

Change-Id: Ife13f8b0a890184d26bb941faec84dcc496c90b4
Closes-bug: #1420048

commit_message:
Remove rubick and milk-dev from gerritbot

These two channels are not setup properly, openstackinfra has no access
to them, milk-dev is not even a registered channel.
The projects are also dead, there has not been any change for them for
several months (last merge in rubick: 2014-06-18, milk: 2014-03-13).

Thus, remove the channels from gerritbot.

Change-Id: I848e36c24797518805cf1e5492a7fec8111cc690

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-03 18:13:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e7379504521ee087c9006b7a2ad5717dd5f06ed2', 'message': "Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket

Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Add a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout

commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection.
Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Add a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout
behaviour. Allows closing idle client connections after a period of
time, eg:

$ time nc localhost 8776
real    1m0.063s

Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

DocImpact:
Added wsgi_keep_alive option (default=True).
Added client_socket_timeout option (default=0).

Conflicts:
        nova/tests/unit/test_wsgi.py

Note: The required unit-tests are manually added to the below path,
as new path for unit-tests is not present in stable/icehouse release.
nova/tests/compute/test_host_api.py

This patch is not 1:1 cherry-pick, I have changed the default value
of client_socket_timeout to 0, as per the policy for changes to
stable branches.
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StableBranch#Appropriate_Fixes)

SecurityImpact

Closes-Bug: #1361360
Change-Id: I399b812f6d452226fd306c423de8dcea8520d2aa
(cherry picked from commit 04d7a724fdf80db51e73f12c5b8c982db9310742)

commit_message:
Add the image extension (for local boot)

Initially this extension supports installing a bootloader so the user
image can boot from the local disk.

Change-Id: Ia588aafc240b55119c02f1254addc0cf796f88c5

commit_message:
VPNaaS: Fix unit test breakage

With the recent refactoring in Neutron, the router creation logic has
changed. This modifies the VPNaaS repo unit tests to be compatible
with these changes. Reference review 147744, which is approved and
awaiting merge.

Note: There were two tests which were testing DVR, but were calling
a router vs a DVR. Didn't seem to affect the test done, however, but
fixed.

Change-Id: Ic310a323462e02a9b1b8989122e7b20444402d1a
Closes-Bug: #1427858

commit_message:
Image building support for fedora hosts

This patch makes the full_trusty_build.sh script to work on Fedora and
install the dependencies needed to build the image.

added_lines: def _create_connection(self, mode): if mode is _WRITER: elif self.synchronous_reader or mode is _ASYNC_READER: def _create_session(self, mode, bind=None): if mode is _WRITER: elif self.synchronous_reader or mode is _ASYNC_READER: self.mode = None mode=self.mode) bind=self.connection, mode=self.mode) if self.mode is _WRITER: if self.mode is _WRITER: def _produce_block(self, mode, connection, savepoint): if mode is _WRITER: elif mode is _ASYNC_READER: if self.mode is None: self.mode = _WRITER elif self.mode is _READER: elif self.mode is _ASYNC_READER: if self.mode is None: self.mode = _READER elif self.mode is _ASYNC_READER: if self.mode is None: self.mode = _ASYNC_READER mode=None, self._mode = mode This method can only be called before any specific transaction-beginning methods have been called. return self._clone(mode=_WRITER) return self._clone(mode=_READER) if self._mode is _WRITER: return self._clone(mode=_ASYNC_READER) "mode": self._mode, if self._mode is not None: mode=self._mode,
deleted_lines: def _create_connection(self, writer): if writer is _WRITER: elif self.synchronous_reader or writer is _ASYNC_READER: def _create_session(self, writer, bind=None): if writer is _WRITER: elif self.synchronous_reader or writer is _ASYNC_READER: self.writer = None writer=self.writer) bind=self.connection, writer=self.writer) if self.writer is _WRITER: if self.writer is _WRITER: def _produce_block(self, writer, connection, savepoint): if writer is _WRITER: elif writer is _ASYNC_READER: if self.writer is None: self.writer = _WRITER elif self.writer is _READER: elif self.writer is _ASYNC_READER: if self.writer is None: self.writer = _READER elif self.writer is _ASYNC_READER: if self.writer is None: self.writer = _ASYNC_READER writer=None, self._writer = writer This method can only be called before any specific transaction-beginning methods have been called. return self._clone(writer=_WRITER) return self._clone(writer=_READER) if self._writer is _WRITER: return self._clone(writer=_ASYNC_READER) "writer": self._writer, if self._writer is not None: writer=self._writer,

commit_message:
Refactor DVR _arp_entry methods

This should decouple the DVR stuff from the agent.  This moves some
methods to dvr_router to encapulate them better.  It removes a
reference to fullsync from DVR to better separate concerns.

Change-Id: Ibf0cec4c44576f7c7196c9780a1b12de96a812b3
Partially-Implements: bp/restructure-l3-agent

added_lines: ri._update_arp_entry(fixed_ip['ip_address'], p['mac_address'], subnet_id, 'add') ri = self.router_info.get(router_id) if not ri: return arp_table = payload['arp_table'] ri._update_arp_entry(ip, mac, subnet_id, 'add') ri = self.router_info.get(router_id) if not ri: return arp_table = payload['arp_table'] ri._update_arp_entry(ip, mac, subnet_id, 'delete')
deleted_lines: self._update_arp_entry(ri, fixed_ip['ip_address'], p['mac_address'], subnet_id, 'add') def get_internal_port(self, ri, subnet_id): """Return internal router port based on subnet_id.""" router_ports = ri.router.get(l3_constants.INTERFACE_KEY, []) for port in router_ports: fips = port['fixed_ips'] for f in fips: if f['subnet_id'] == subnet_id: return port def _update_arp_entry(self, ri, ip, mac, subnet_id, operation): """Add or delete arp entry into router namespace for the subnet.""" port = self.get_internal_port(ri, subnet_id) # update arp entry only if the subnet is attached to the router if port: ip_cidr = str(ip) + '/32' try: # TODO(mrsmith): optimize the calls below for bulk calls net = netaddr.IPNetwork(ip_cidr) interface_name = self.get_internal_device_name(port['id']) device = ip_lib.IPDevice(interface_name, namespace=ri.ns_name) if operation == 'add': device.neigh.add(net.version, ip, mac) elif operation == 'delete': device.neigh.delete(net.version, ip, mac) except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE("DVR: Failed updating arp entry")) self.fullsync = True arp_table = payload['arp_table'] ri = self.router_info.get(router_id) if ri: self._update_arp_entry(ri, ip, mac, subnet_id, 'add') arp_table = payload['arp_table'] ri = self.router_info.get(router_id) if ri: self._update_arp_entry(ri, ip, mac, subnet_id, 'delete')

commit_message:
Set Tempest authentication endpoints to global default

This change removes redundant concatenation by replacing the endpoints
with ones pre-defined as global variables.

This also allows the endpoint to be overwritten if necessary.

Change-Id: I381d1d7b9fdf47f9f8c2474225679407d37e06af
Closes-Bug: #1424729

commit_message:
Make config files created by stask.sh more secure

Bugfix 1257599. stack.sh used to leave config files with keystone token
and database credentials readable for all. This change makes sure that
all below files have 640 permissions:
    /etc/keystone/keystone.conf
    /etc/nova/nova.conf
    /etc/heat/heat.conf
    /etc/cinder/cinder.conf
    /etc/glance/{glance-api.conf,glance-api-paste.ini,glance-registry.conf}
    /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf
    /etc/neutron/neutron.conf
Additionally set the same permissions for /etc/neutron/rootwrap.conf which
contains XenServer xapi credentials.

Change-Id: I9f8b703aa7e4f064656141a548bff014be500daf

commit_message:
ensure we reset contexts when fixture is used

Previously using the ClearRequestContext fixture only reset contexts
on fixture teardown. If *all* tests in a test suite use this fixture,
this is fine. However if any tests do not, it means you might start
with a carry over context from previous tests.

Using this fixture means you really wanted a clean slate, so fix it so
that you get a clean state when you get started as well as when you
finish.

Change-Id: I5e6f7bc2866fe66f269c7d5e1f36c711151489c2
Closes-Bug: #1428728

added_lines: def test_store_current_resets_correctly(self): # By default a new context is stored. ctx = context.RequestContext() # the use of the fixture should put us in a reset state, not # doing so is a bug because when this fixture is consumed by # other test suites there is no guaruntee that all tests use # this fixture. self.useFixture(fixture.ClearRequestContext()) self.assertIsNone(context.get_current()) ctx = context.RequestContext() self.assertIs(context.get_current(), ctx) fixture.ClearRequestContext()._remove_cached_context() self.assertIsNone(context.get_current())

commit_message:
Fixed pool and health monitor create bugs

lbaas-pool-create now accepts --name as an optional argument and no longer lists
healthmonitor_id as an acceptable argument.  lbaas-create-healthmonitor
now accepts --pool as an argument so a healthmonitor can be added
to a pool.

Change-Id: I7c5ae61a5278119bf5c3999f4b295bd8a291d777
Closes-Bug: #1426246
Closes-Bug: #1426253

commit_message:
Add mako templating plugin and XSS profile

Adds plugin to warn on Mako templates. Since mako does not have template wide
autoescaping (that we can verify is turned on), a developer is responsible to
escape each variable individually in the templates. This is higher than info
because the *only* way to escape is via the variables, but not set to ERROR
because we can't know for sure if any of those variables are used and/or
malicious.

Also add an XSS profile.

Change-Id: I65515f9584d67d8b7b58b71b6ddb447c307675d1

Replace the basic http request testing with requests-mock rather than
using mocking.

commit_message:
Set headers on object before creating/updating

We're not currently sending on headers from Object.create, so while we
can create objects, we can't set metadata key/value pairs on them at the
same time. Adding a set headers solves this.

Change-Id: Ie3bbebbdcff32152c0f433257606844ff1120ef8

commit_message:
Allow providing a logger to save_and_reraise_exception

Instead of always assuming the best logger to use when
a exception is being dropped is the root logger (which
it may not always be) allow for providing a custom
logger when using this functionality + class so that
users can direct it to a logger of there choosing.

Change-Id: Ic56892be9d007229f5c302a2c6da19f00e91752e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/58/158158/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, reraise=True): logging.error(_LE('Original exception being dropped: %s'), traceback.format_exception(self.type_, self.value, self.tb))

commit_message:
deprecate policy_dirs option

It is not clear why this is a configurable option. The original
blueprint just wanted the ability to specify a policy.d infrastructure
to make complex policies easier to enforce. There was no requirement
on it being configurable.

Being configurable just exposes another way in which incompatibilities
in OpenStack projects might be able to emerge. As this merged late in
the incubator lifecycle for the policy code, there are likely few/no
existing users of the option so it should be safe to deprecate it
for the library.  That way we won't break anyone currently using it,
and don't have to commit to supporting it going forward.

Co-Authored-By: Steve Martinelli <stevemar@ca.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I40bcbfbd4ab626fa9bfa050792e9ed3cfb587225

commit_message:
Add flat network gateway to br-vlan for AIO builds

When an AIO is built using the included scripts and networking config,
the public network has a gateway IP of 172.29.248.1 from the
172.29.248.0/22 network, which is not expected or configured to exist
anywhere. This can cause issues when using floats or in general if
some communication is desired which uses the public side gateway of
the neutron-routed network.

A simple solution is to simply drop 172.29.248.1/22 on br-vlan via the
interface config, which allows the traffic to do the needful, at least
as far as tempest's requirements are concerned. In modern
Debian/Ubuntu, this can be accomplished with another "iface" stanza
with its own "address" directive to add the additional address.

Change-Id: I79897bc4e4d7eb7d55ad3c12f55a339dfef869e1
Closes-Bug: #1425717
Related-Bug: #1425255
(cherry picked from commit 0737a6062c2e1c96706bd0289c652dc3802802c2)

Conflicts:
	etc/network/interfaces.d/aio_interfaces.cfg

Change-Id: Ie1f9829e3b3cc494f2c5d178013513f276b88a8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/77/161777/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Add an additional address to br-vlan iface br-vlan inet static # Flat network default gateway # -- This needs to exist somewhere for network reachability # -- from the router namespace for floating IP paths. # -- Putting this here is primarily for tempest to work. address 172.29.248.1 netmask 255.255.252.0

commit_message:
Modified l2gateway-create/update CLI

Replacing ":" with "|" to seperate interface-name and
segmentation-id in l2-gateway-create and l2-gateway-update
CLIs.Help text is also changed.

Change-Id: I30a7bea26905df72c1864f1f5d3ded6c3b355977

commit_message:
Reduce the load on functional tests

Starting with a default of 10 nested stacks is a bit heavy and
not necessary for the logic of the tests. This seems to also
cause false failures as it can timeout.

Change-Id: I51ea045a51884857169f4588a4fc9c67d23dd153

This patch allows the SQLAlchemy DB API to talk to any arbitrary
database if connection_url is explicitly specified. If no connection_url
is specified, it connects to the default (Nova) engine. This is achieved
by using a defaultdict as the engine store with connection URLs serving
as keys and corresponding engines being the values. For the default engine
the key is 'None'.

not been changed. In reality, each DB API function, model_query function
and NovaBase.save() function will accept two more parameters
'connection_url' and 'params' which will be passed to the get_engine/
get_session calls.

Change-Id: Iee3932ece4a00ca46f8508d41c130b9061bee818

commit_message:
Allow DB API to connect to arbitrary database for cellsv2

This patch allows the SQLAlchemy DB API to talk to any arbitrary
database. It allows augmenting existing request context with the connection
information of the target database and the uses the augmented context to
instantiate the SQLAlchemy engine/session objects.
If the default unaugmented context is used, the DB API connects to the database
specified in the configuration file.

Change-Id: Iee3932ece4a00ca46f8508d41c130b9061bee818
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/150381/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _ENGINE_FACADE = collections.defaultdict( lambda: None)def _create_facade_lazily(connection_url=None, params=None): if _ENGINE_FACADE[connection_url] is None: with _LOCK: if _ENGINE_FACADE[connection_url] is None: if connection_url is None: _create_fn = db_session.EngineFacade.from_config _ENGINE_FACADE[connection_url] = _create_fn(CONF) else: if params is None: params = {} _create_fn = db_session.EngineFacade _ENGINE_FACADE[connection_url] = _create_fn( connection_url, **params) return _ENGINE_FACADE[connection_url] def get_engine(use_slave=False, connection_url=None, params=None): facade = _create_facade_lazily(connection_url=connection_url, params=params)def get_session(use_slave=False, connection_url=None, params=None, **kwargs): facade = _create_facade_lazily(connection_url=connection_url, params=params)
deleted_lines: _ENGINE_FACADE = Nonedef _create_facade_lazily(): if _ENGINE_FACADE is None: with _LOCK: if _ENGINE_FACADE is None: _ENGINE_FACADE = db_session.EngineFacade.from_config(CONF) return _ENGINE_FACADE def get_engine(use_slave=False): facade = _create_facade_lazily()def get_session(use_slave=False, **kwargs): facade = _create_facade_lazily()

'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-02-06 18:24:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a864b0bb3b5da44527057bdabc848541b4c7487e', 'message': 'Refactor management of namespaces in the L3 Agent

Creates classes representing the 3 types of namespaces handled by the L3 agent:
router, snat and fip.

The scope of this change is:

- Creation and deletion methods are provided for each namespace class
- Creation and deletion of router and snat namespaces are moved to the router
  classes. These namespaces are now members of the corresponding router class
- Invocation of Fip namespace creation and deletion is left in the agent, since
  the agent owns it
- A context manager is provided to move the namespaces (router and snat)
  cleanup code out of the agent

A follow up patchset will add methods to create and delete interfaces in the
namespaces. These methods are intended to be used by the router classes

Change-Id: I54b14e593ded6b2990d57a3ae9d598a699ae133e
Partially-Implements: bp restructure-l3-agent

commit_message:
Refactor management of namespaces in the L3 Agent

Creates classes representing the 3 types of namespaces handled by the L3 agent:
router, snat and fip.

The scope of this change is:

- Creation and deletion methods are provided for each namespace class
- Creation and deletion of router and snat namespaces are moved to the router
  classes. These namespaces are now members of the corresponding router class
- Invocation of Fip namespace creation and deletion is left in the agent, since
  the agent owns it
- A context manager is provided to move the namespaces (router and snat)
  cleanup code out of the agent

A follow up patchset will add methods to create and delete interfaces in the
namespaces. These methods are intended to be used by the router classes

Change-Id: I54b14e593ded6b2990d57a3ae9d598a699ae133e
Partially-Implements: bp restructure-l3-agent
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/44/147744/33 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # from neutron.agent.linux import ip_lib from neutron.agent.linux import ra from neutron.i18n import _LE from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) NS_PREFIX = 'qrouter-' INTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX = 'qr-' EXTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX = 'qg-' SNAT_NS_PREFIX = 'snat-' SNAT_INT_DEV_PREFIX = 'sg-' FIP_NS_PREFIX = 'fip-' FIP_2_ROUTER_DEV_PREFIX = 'fpr-' FIP_EXT_DEV_PREFIX = 'fg-' ROUTER_2_FIP_DEV_PREFIX = 'rfp-' class Namespace(object): def __init__(self, name, root_helper): self.name = name self.root_helper = root_helper self.ip_wrapper = ip_lib.IPWrapper(self.root_helper, name) def create(self): ip_wrapper_root = ip_lib.IPWrapper(self.root_helper) self.ip_wrapper = ip_wrapper_root.ensure_namespace(self.name) class L3Namespace(Namespace): def __init__(self, name, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6): super(L3Namespace, self).__init__(name, root_helper) self.agent_conf = agent_conf self.driver = driver self.use_ipv6 = use_ipv6 def create(self): super(L3Namespace, self).__init__() cmd = ['sysctl', '-w', 'net.ipv4.ip_forward=1'] self.ip_wrapper.netns.execute(cmd) if self.use_ipv6: cmd = ['sysctl', '-w', 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding=1'] self.ip_wrapper.netns.execute(cmd) def delete(self): try: self.ip_wrapper.netns.delete(self.name) except RuntimeError: msg = _LE('Failed trying to delete namespace: %s') LOG.exception(msg, self.name) class RouterNamespace(L3Namespace): def __init__(self, router_id, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6): self.router_id = router_id name = NS_PREFIX + router_id super(RouterNamespace, self).__init__(name, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6) def destroy(self): ra.disable_ipv6_ra(self.router_id, self.name, self.root_helper) ns_ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(self.root_helper, namespace=self.name) for d in ns_ip.get_devices(exclude_loopback=True): if d.name.startswith(INTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX): # device is on default bridge self.driver.unplug(d.name, namespace=self.name, prefix=INTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX) elif d.name.startswith(ROUTER_2_FIP_DEV_PREFIX): ns_ip.del_veth(d.name) elif d.name.startswith(EXTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX): self.driver.unplug( d.name, bridge=self.agent_conf.external_network_bridge, namespace=self.name, prefix=EXTERNAL_DEV_PREFIX) if self.agent_conf.router_delete_namespaces: self.delete() class SnatNamespace(L3Namespace): def __init__(self, router_id, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6): self.router_id = router_id name = SNAT_NS_PREFIX + router_id super(RouterNamespace, self).__init__(name, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6) def destroy(self): ns_ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(self.root_helper, namespace=self.name) for d in ns_ip.get_devices(exclude_loopback=True): if d.name.startswith(SNAT_INT_DEV_PREFIX): LOG.debug('Unplugging DVR device %s', d.name) self.driver.unplug(d.name, namespace=self.name, prefix=SNAT_INT_DEV_PREFIX) LOG.debug('DVR: destroy snat ns: %s', self.name) if self.agent_conf.router_delete_namespaces: self.delete() class FipNamespace(L3Namespace): def __init__(self, ext_net_id, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6): self.router_id = ext_net_id name = FIP_NS_PREFIX + ext_net_id super(RouterNamespace, self).__init__(name, agent_conf, driver, root_helper, use_ipv6) def destroy(self): ns_ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(self.root_helper, namespace=self.name) for d in ns_ip.get_devices(exclude_loopback=True): if d.name.startswith(FIP_2_ROUTER_DEV_PREFIX): # internal link between IRs and FIP NS ns_ip.del_veth(d.name) elif d.name.startswith(FIP_EXT_DEV_PREFIX): # single port from FIP NS to br-ext # TODO(carl) Where does the port get deleted? LOG.debug('DVR: unplug: %s', d.name) self.driver.unplug(d.name, bridge=self.conf.external_network_bridge, namespace=self.name, prefix=FIP_EXT_DEV_PREFIX) LOG.debug('DVR: destroy fip ns: %s', self.name) # TODO(mrsmith): add LOG warn if fip count != 0 if self.conf.router_delete_namespaces: self.delete() class RootNamespace(object): def create(self): pass def delete(self): pass

commit_message:
Service Class Cleanup - Part 1/3

Here, we rework the various Service base classes to have a standard
constructor format, in preperation for turning the RPC/DNS/WSGI
Service classes into mixins, allowing for MiniDNS to be both a
RPC and DNS Service - sharing code with Central etc (RPCService) and
the Agent (DNSService).

Part two will turn each Service sub-class into a mixin.
Part three will move MiniDNS to using the DNSService mixin.

Change-Id: I1647f2036232d1bedfa3b3f79837dc0c808a2700

'}]

commit_message:
Change using flavor in Heat OSTF test 'test_advanced_actions'

In the test 'test_advanced_actions' test vm flavor was used, but
now we have to use special micro flavor and got its name by
find_micro_flavor() function.

Closes-Bug: #1428565

Change-Id: I5cd0eeed17d6b9c6920064b20940088742e31110
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ostf refs/changes/89/161689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "InstanceType": self.find_micro_flavor()[0].name,
