subject: Rename the blockdev to disk driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-04 18:24:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/a74c53af939f89512f771f6946661ae7b64b68ad', 'message': "Rename the blockdev to disk driver

The original code had a 'blockdev' which represented local disk types.
However, with volume support, the term 'block' became ambiguous.  This
change set modifies the blockdev to be named as a 'driver' under the
disk folder.

This provides consistency with the volume driver.

Also updated the generic 'StorageAdapter' within blockdev to be a
'DiskAdapter'.  That more accurately describes its purpose.

Change-Id: I96f881109f6ad362c9fea2051bb38b79789d27f0

commit_message:
Rename the blockdev to disk driver

The original code had a 'blockdev' which represented local disk types.
However, with volume support, the term 'block' became ambiguous.  This
change set modifies the blockdev to be named as a 'driver' under the
disk folder.

This provides consistency with the volume driver.

Also updated the generic 'StorageAdapter' within blockdev to be a
'DiskAdapter'.  That more accurately describes its purpose.

Change-Id: I96f881109f6ad362c9fea2051bb38b79789d27f0

commit_message:
Include Relationships and extend other murano datasource tables

Revise murano-driver to extend the tables to include more data
from API.  Parent_types now includes all object's ancestor type,
including its own type.  Objects includes defaultNetwork from
deployments API.  Properties now includes all available properties
instead of select ones.  Data is populated to the Relationships
for certain environment/services configuration. Workaround is
added for 401 error issue which is similar to bug 1422582.

Implements: blueprint murano-driver

Change-Id: Iccb1d49eb006b49bd214f6c3181b05b406e4584e

commit_message:
Make service_create return 400 status on empty manifest

Currently in service_create API when both manifest
and manifest_url is not defined, 500 status was
returned to user. This patch makes servic_create
API to return 400 status when both is not passed.

Change-Id: I94571bcebf7eb87a79c7c1f6882a50931bba857d
Closes-bug: #1424533

commit_message:
Spec for congress workflow

Change-Id: I42f953ebc225559bf91441581f925bf802c3bf45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/18/125218/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Congress Workflow Description ========================================== Introduction ============= Congress targets to provide an extensible framework for governance and compliance across any cloud services existing today. The congress policy service will enable IT services in a human consumable and yet feasible to implementable abstraction. In the highlevel, Congress may not directly modify/update the state of any cloud services. Instead, it will leave the delegation of the underneath policy drivers and dedicated cloud service components (e.g. Nova in Openstack) to update the cloud services to the defined and compliant state. In the scope of the Openstack, Congress can enforce policy in the cloud services via the Heat, Nova, Swift, and Neutron. To better illustrate the potential scenario, this specification provides the workflow of using Congress, from the Congress policy definition to Neutron Group Based Policy (GBP) integration. The workflows of Congress to other cloud service components may follow the same principle in the , and will not be covered in this specification. Several different workflow models are discussed. Problem Description =================== We wanted to tackle a number of items: Specific for networking: where is the source of truth - describe what congress pulls up or pushes down 1.2) Congress as the single source of truth - publishing/pushing down partial/full information for other components to provision against 1.3) GBP as the single source of truth - congress pulling/receiving information from GBP to validate against policy 1.4) Cooperative sourcing of truth - congress requires GBP member information for validation; GBP requires congress policy to determine contracts (& derivatives of this scenario) 1.5) Both GBP and Congress are sources of truth - this is really the starting point imho; multiple sources are gathered in Congress to then perform policy validation or- troubleshooting tasks on. Contributors ============ Congress Interaction ===================== (Jim, Yapeng) Congress Workflow Models ======================== (All) Congress Workflow focuses on the congress integration with Neutron Policy functionality, a policy driver for neutron, specifically the Group Based Policy (GBP). In general there are three potential models for Congress to interact with GBP: Model A: Congress manages all policies, including network policies, and pushes the policy to the underneath network policy drivers. This model can also be called as Publish Model. Model B: where group membership comes from GBP and contract comes from Congress. Hybrid Model Model C: Congress validates/checks what GBP has. Pull Model Mode D: (? not being mentioned, or should we think it is combination of the above and not need a seperate topic) Publish Model Workflow ======================= (Jim, Yapeng) Hybrid Model Workflow ===================== (Nils) Pull Model Workflow =================== (Rukhsana) Proposed change =============== Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== References ========== None

commit_message:
Make use_syslog=True log to syslog via /dev/log

After upgrade from Icehouse to Juno OpenStack services don't log to
syslog via /dev/log anymore. This behaviour was introduced in commit
1188d88a73e75da5c143d0dfad34e10dad0daee0. While /dev/log is arguably
not a very portable default, breaking the backwards compatibility is
even worse.
This commit restores the original behaviour. /dev/log portability
issues will be addressed separately.
Closes-Bug: #1385295
Related-Bug: #1391428

Change-Id: I5c450595fde7451a5bf9372430a53e75dd5773a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/06/159606/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: syslog = handlers.RFCSysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility) else: syslog = logging.handlers.SysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility)

commit_message:
Enable secret decrypt through 'payload' resource

With this change, it is now possible to decrypt secrets through the
usage of a 'payload' resource such as the following:

GET <host>/v1/secrets/<secret ID>/payload

The relevant tests were added to use this new scheme, yet, support
for the other scheme cannot be dropped until this lands to the client
code.

Blueprint api-change-get-secrets-decrypted
APIImpact

Change-Id: I2c3a885b11f86014c0111ccac10ca7e23b7f710f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/68/157068/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import testtools @testtools.skip("To be enforced later.") def test_should_raise_if_get_secret_metadata_with_non_json_content_type( self): resp = self.app.get( '/secrets/{0}/'.format(self.secret.id), headers={'Accept': 'text/plain', 'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip'} ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) '/secrets/{0}/payload/'.format(self.secret.id), ('/secrets/{0}/payload/' '?trans_wrapped_session_key={1}&transport_key_id={2}') '/secrets/{0}/payload/?trans_wrapped_session_key={1}'.format( '/secrets/{0}/payload/'.format(self.secret.id), '/secrets/{0}/payload/'.format(self.secret.id), def test_should_only_allow_get_for_secret_payload_uri(self): resp = self.app.post( '/secrets/{0}/payload/'.format(self.secret.id), 'plain text', headers={'Accept': 'text/plain'}, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 405) resp = self.app.put( '/secrets/{0}/payload/'.format(self.secret.id), 'plain text', headers={'Accept': 'text/plain'}, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 405) resp = self.app.delete( '/secrets/{0}/payload/'.format(self.secret.id), 'plain text', headers={'Accept': 'text/plain'}, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 405)

commit_message:
Update to Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

* image/ubuntu:
  - make sure puppet agent is not started during OS boot
  - catch up the new ruby packages naming convention
  - don't install Mellanox related packages (should be reverted
    after rebuilding those packages for Ubuntu 14.04)
* requirements-deb.txt:
  - adapt to the packages' names changes (guestmount -> libguestfs-tools)
  - use the default version of ruby (ruby 1.8 is not available any more),
    catch up the new ruby packages naming convention.
  - dhcp-checker is gone, long live nailgun-net-checker.
  - temporarily skip Mellanox related packages (until they get rebuild
    for Ubuntu 14.04)
* config.mk:
  - use the new OBS APT repository
* packages/deb/specs:
  - nailgun-agent, fencing-agent: depend on ohai, so the custom ruby-ohai
    package (which actually contains the identical code) is not required
    any more
  - temporarily remove nailgun-agent and fencing-agent from requiremets-deb.txt

Implements: blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty
Change-Id: I4300b892c1fbb8d1dfa8bdd18815d56bcabe324d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/73/143973/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # puppet agents get automatically started in recent Ubuntu versions. # This confuses astute so it aborts the deployment (see # https://bugs.launchpad.net/mos/+bug/1385079) sudo chroot ${TMP_CHROOT_DIR} update-rc.d puppet disable

commit_message:
Add basic support for conditional execution

Change-Id: Id7bbdc2518efbbefe2a2e3be4d3a685ac930b2ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/46/98946/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================= Conditional execution ======================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/taskflow/+spec/conditional-flow-choices Allow a level of conditional execution of compiled `atoms`_ & associated `flows`_ (aka workflows) that can be used to alter the execution *path* based on some type of condition. .. _atoms: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/taskflow/atoms.html#atom .. _flows: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/taskflow/patterns.html Problem description =================== Mistral and cinder would like to be able to conditionally have a atom (or subflow) execute based on some type of selection made by either a prior atom or by an error or by a function (for example). This kind of conditional execution right now is difficult currently in taskflow since we compile a workflow into a directed graph, verify inputs and outputs that each atom provides, create entries that track the atoms state and outputs (similar to a computers memory) and then execute. Conditional execution alters this since now we can not at compile time make a descision about whether a atom will or will not execute (since it is not known until runtime whether the atom actually will) so we need to address this to provide at least a *basic* level of support to accomplish a type of conditional execution. Proposed change =============== In order to support conditionals we first need to determine what a conditional means in a workflow, to make it simple (to start) let's limit the scope and suggest that a conditional is restricted to being a runtime scheduling choice that causes the path of execution to ``IGNORE`` X - 1 of X subgraphs and only ``ACTIVATE`` 1 of X subgraphs. This means that at compile time phase when a conditional is inserted into a flow that any attached outcomes of the conditional must satisfy all existing compilation validation strategies (requirements checking for example will enforce that any subgraph of the conditional must have inputs that are provided by some predecessor and that any outcome can provide inputs that satisify some other atom can depend on (just as they usually would). The next thing a conditional then needs a mechanism to influence the *outcome* which should be executed to one of the X subgraphs at runtime. To accomplish this the conditional needs the ability firstly to know what those potential outcomes are to decide what it can choose from. This is where the imperative paradigm would be a nice to *just* use as it can use local state, make a decision about that local state and keep on executing but since a flow is declarative we need another approach to solve this puzzle. A solution that comes to mind that work (but there could be other solutions that also work): * When a conditional is encountered while executing (assume there is some way to know that we have *hit* a conditional) we need to first freeze execution of any successors (nothing must execute in any outcomes subgraph ahead of time, this would violate the conditional constraint). Note that this does not mean that a subgraph executing that is not connected to this conditional will have to be stopped (its execution is not dependent on this outcome decision). So assuming we can freeze dependent execution (which we currently can do) we now need to provide the conditional a way to make a decision (usually the decision will be based on some prior execution or other external state). We have a mechanism for doing this already so we will continue using the existing requirements mechanism to communicate any state (local or otherwise). Now the conditional just needs to be able to pick which outcome should be executed so that the runtime can continue down that execution path. A potential options comes to mind here, one that can be flexible enough to allow for various further kind of conditionals to be implemented. The idea is that the conditional will be provided as input the successors subgraphs (in read-only mode) that *could* execute and each will have a unique name/identifier associated with it, the conditional will then use whatever internal logic to pick which one of those subgraphs should be executed and it will return this. This would complete a decision based on some provided inputs, and some potential set of outcomes, creating a simple but *hopefully* powerful mechanism for doing conditional like execution (without losing the benefits of the declarative paradigm). Conditionals have another an interesting interaction with retry logic, in that when a subgraph is retried, we must decide what to do about the X - 1 outcomes which were not traversed and decide if we should allow the prior outcome decision to be altered. This means that when a execution graph is retried it can be possible to enter a new subgraph (which may contain its own new set of retry strategies and so-on). To start we will *clear* the outcome of a conditional when a retry resets a conditional object (and causes it to be executed again), this will allow the most natural integration with the existing codebase (and is likely what users would expect to happen). Alternatives ------------ WIP Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- This will require a new type that when encountered can be used to decide which outcome should taken. This new type will be a publicly useable type that can be dependened upon working as expected (observing and operating by the constraints described above). Security impact --------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Configuration Impact -------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- A new way of using taskflow would be introduced that would hopefully recieve usage and mature as taskflow continues to progress. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: harlowja Milestones ---------- Juno/2 Work Items ---------- * Introduce new conditional type. * Connect conditional into compilation routine. * Connect conditional into scheduling/runtime routine. * Test like crazy. Incubation ========== N/A Adoption -------- N/A Library ------- N/A Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- N/A Documentation Impact ==================== New developer docs explaining the concepts, how to use this and examples will be provided and updated accordingly. Dependencies ============ None References ========== * Brainstorm: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BrainstormFlowConditions * Prototype: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/87417/ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/12/160212/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>In the planning and design phases of the build out, it is important to include the operation's function. Operational factors affect the design choices for a general purpose cloud, and operations staff are often tasked with the maintenance of cloud environments for larger installations.</para> <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>Maintenance tasks</term> <para>The storage solution should take </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>Reliability and availability</term> <para>Reliability and </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>Flexibility</term> <para>Organizations need to have the </varlistentry> </variablelist> <para>Installing and configuring monitoring and alerting services are vitally important in cloud environments with high demands on storage resources. These services provide a real-time view into the health and performance of the storage systems.Using an integrated SNMP data, is helpful when discovering and resolving issues that arise within the storage cluster.</para> <para>Ease of management of the storage devices is an important consideration when designing a storage solution. Operations personnel provide ongoing maintenance of the storage hardware.</para> storage hardware results in a solution which is easy to replication, retention, data backup and recovery.</para> </section> <para>Designing applications to be aware of the underlying storage subsystem and the features available will leverage storage solutions in the cloud.</para> <para>When creating an application that requires infrastructure.</para> </section> comparing the Block Storage and Object Storage services. The Object Storage service is designed to have consistency and controllers to provide redundancy for physical disks.</para> <section xml:id="block-storage-fault-tolerance-and-availability"> <title>Block Storage fault tolerance and availability</title> <para>Block Storage resource nodes are commonly configured with advanced RAID controllers and high performance disks that are designed to provide fault tolerance at the hardware level.</para> <para>We recommend you deploy high performing storage solutions such as SSD disk drives or flash storage systems in cases where applications require extreme performance out of Block Storage devices. It is important to consider the availability of software and support to ease with the hardware and software integration process when considering these solutions.</para> <para>In environments that place extreme demands on Block Storage, it is advisable to take advantage of multiple storage pools. In this case, each pool of devices should have a similar hardware design and disk configuration across all hardware nodes in that pool. This allows for a design that provides applications with access to a wide variety of Block Storage pools, each with their own redundancy, availability, and performance characteristics. When deploying multiple pools of storage it is also important to consider the impact on the Block Storage scheduler which is responsible for provisioning storage across resource nodes. Ensuring that applications can schedule volumes in multiple regions, each with their own network, power, and cooling infrastructure, can give tenants the ability to build fault tolerant applications that will be distributed across multiple availability zones.</para> <para>In addition to the Block Storage resource nodes, it is important to design for high availability and redundancy of the APIs and related services that are responsible for provisioning and providing access to storage. We recommend desiging a layer of hardware or software load balancers in order to achieve high availability of the appropriate REST API services to provide uninterrupted service. In some cases, it may also be necessary to deploy an additional layer of load balancing to provide access to back-end database services responsible for servicing and storing the state of Block Storage volumes. We also recommend designing a highly available database solution to store the Block Storage databases. A number of highly available database solutions such as Galera and MariaDB can be leveraged to help keep database services online to provide uninterrupted access so that tenants can manage Block Storage volumes.</para> <para>In a cloud with extreme demands on Block Storage, the network architecture should take into account the amount of East-West bandwidth that will be required for instances to make use of the available storage resources. Network devices selected should support jumbo frames for transferring large blocks of data. In some cases, it may be necessary to create an additional back-end storage network dedicated to providing connectivity between instances and Block Storage resources so that there is no contention of network resources.</para> </section> <section xml:id="object-storage-fault-tolerance-and-availability"> <title>Object Storage fault tolerance and availability</title> <para>While consistency and partition tolerance are both inherent features of the Object Storage service, it is important to design the overall storage architecture to ensure that those goals are met by the system being implemented. The OpenStack Object Storage service places a specific number of data replicas as objects on resource nodes. These replicas are distributed throughout the cluster based on a consistent hash ring which exists on all nodes in the cluster.</para> <para>The Object Storage system should be designed with sufficient number of zones to provide quorum for the number of replicas defined. As an example, with three replicas configured in the Swift cluster, the recommended number of zones to configure within the Object Storage cluster in order to achieve quorum is 5. While it is possible to deploy a solution with fewer zones, the implied risk of doing so is that some data may not be available and API requests to certain objects stored in the cluster might fail. For this reason, ensure the number of zones in the Object Storage cluster is properly accounted for.</para> <para>Each Object Storage zone should be self-contained within its own availability zone. Each availability zone should have independent access to network, power and cooling infrastructure to ensure uninterrupted access to data. In addition, each availability zone should be serviced by a pool of Object Storage proxy servers which will provide access to data stored on the object nodes. Object proxies in each region should leverage local read and write affinity so that access to objects is facilitated by local storage resources wherever possible. We recommend that upstream load balancing be deployed to ensure that proxy services can be distributed across the multiple zones and, in some cases, it may be necessary to make use of third party solutions to aid with geographical distribution of services.</para> <para>A zone within an Object Storage cluster is a logical division. A zone can be represented as any of the following:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> A disk with a single node. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> The node itself. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> A group of nodes in a rack. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> An entire rack. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Data center or geographical region. </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>Deciding on the proper zone design is crucial for allowing the object storage cluster to scale while providing an available and redundant storage system. It may be necessary to configure storage policies that have different requirements with regards to replicas, retention and other factors that could heavily affect the design of storage in a specific zone.</para> </section> </section> process when comparing the Block and Object Storage services. While adding Block Storage capacity is a relatively simple process, adding capacity and bandwidth to the Object Storage consideration during the design phase.</para> <section xml:id="scaling-block-storage"> <title>Scaling Block Storage</title> <para>Block storage pools can be upgraded to add storage capacity rather easily without interruption to the overall Block Storage service. Nodes can be added to the pool by simply installing and configuring the appropriate hardware and software and then allowing that node to report in to the proper storage pool via the message bus. This is because Block Storage nodes report into the scheduler service advertising their availability. Once the node is online and available tenants can make use of those storage resources instantly.</para> <para>In some cases, the demand on Block Storage from instances may exhaust the available network bandwidth. As a result, design network infrastructure that services Block Storage resources in such a way that capacity and bandwidth can be added relatively easily. This often involves the use of dynamic routing protocols or advanced networking solutions to allow capacity to be added to downstream devices easily. Both the front-end and back-end storage network designs should encompass the ability to quickly and easily add capacity and bandwidth.</para> </section> <section xml:id="scaling-object-storage"> <title>Scaling Object Storage</title> <para>Adding back-end storage capacity to an Object Storage cluster requires careful planning and consideration. In the design phase it is important to determine the maximum partition power required by the Object Storage service, which determines the maximum number of partitions which can exist. Object Storage distributes data among all available storage, but a partition cannot span more than one disk, so the maximum number of partitions can only be as high as the number of disks.</para> <para>For example, a system that starts with a single disk and a partition power of 3 can have 8 (2^3) partitions. Adding a second disk means that each will have 4 partitions. The one-disk-per-partition limit means that this system can never have more than 8 disks, limiting its scalability. However, a system that starts with a single disk and a partition power of 10 can have up to 1024 (2^10) disks.</para> <para>As back-end storage capacity is added to the system, the partition maps cause data to be redistributed amongst storage nodes. In some cases, this replication can consist of extremely large data sets. In these cases, we recommended making use of back-end replication links which will not contend with tenants' access to data.</para> <para>As more tenants begin to access data within the cluster and their data sets grow it will become necessary to add front-end bandwidth to service data access requests. Adding front-end bandwidth to an Object Storage cluster requires careful planning and design of the Object Storage proxies that will be used by tenants to gain access to the data, along with the high availability solutions that enable easy scaling of the proxy layer. We recommend designing a front-end load balancing layer that tenants and consumers use to gain access to data stored within the cluster. This load balancing layer may be distributed across zones, regions or even across geographic boundaries, which may also require that the design encompass geo-location solutions.</para> <para>In some cases, adding bandwidth and capacity to the network resources servicing requests between proxy servers and storage nodes will be required. For this reason, the network architecture used for access to storage nodes and proxy servers should make use of a design which is scalable.</para> </section> </section>

Using an integrated SNMP data, will be helpful in discovering and resolving issues that might arise within the storage cluster. An example of this is Ceph's Calamari.</para> <para>When designing a storage solution at scale, ease of management of the storage devices is an important consideration. Within a storage cluster, operations personnel provide ongoing maintenance of the storage hardware. When the cloud is designed and planned properly, the process can be performed in a seamless and organized manner that does not have an impact on operational efficiency.</para> storage hardware will result in a solution which is easy to replication, retention, data backup and recovery.</para></section> <para>When designing applications that will leverage storage solutions in the cloud, design the application to be aware of the underlying storage subsystem and the features available. The object storage service is designed to have consistency and controllers to provide redundancy for physical disks. In contrast, block storage resource nodes are commonly configured with advanced RAID controllers and high performance disks that are designed to provide fault tolerance at the hardware level.</para> <para>In cases where applications require extreme performance out of block storage devices, we recommend you deploy high performing storage solutions such as SSD disk drives or flash storage systems. When considering these solutions, it is important to consider the availability of software and support to ease with the hardware and software integration process.</para> <para>In environments that place extreme demands on block storage, it is advisable to take advantage of multiple storage pools. In this case, each pool of devices should have a similar hardware design and disk configuration across all hardware nodes in that pool. This allows for a design that provides applications with access to a wide variety of block storage pools, each with their own redundancy, availability, and performance characteristics. When deploying multiple pools of storage it is also important to consider the impact on the block storage scheduler which is responsible for provisioning storage across resource nodes. In some cases, it may also be necessary to deploy an additional layer of load balancing to provide access to back-end database services responsible for servicing and storing the state of block storage volumes. Designing a highly available database solution to store the Block Storage databases is also recommended. A number of highly available database solutions such as Galera and MariaDB can be leveraged to help keep database services online to provide uninterrupted access so that tenants can manage block storage volumes.</para> <para>In a cloud with extreme demands on block storage the network architecture should take into account the amount of East-West bandwidth that will be required for instances to make use of the available storage resources. Network devices selected should support jumbo frames for transferring large blocks of data. revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-25 14:41:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib/commit/f139a0265c61c7a8f01554d5a77eaa4595acea0a', 'message': "Handle missing launchpadlib gracefully

The use of launchpadlib should not be required for tempest-lib, however
because we wanted to expose the skip_tracker as an entry point and
package it with the library an import to launchpadlib was needed in the
packaged source, which normally should require an entry in the
requirements file. This commit addresses that by making the
launchpadlib use not mandatory. The script will check if launchpadlib
is available and if it isn't the skip tracker will just exit after it

Change-Id: I59814346e899e366734caaf757eb2d8fe5ecbcf7
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-04 01:02:44.000000000', 'files': ['tempest_lib/cmd/skip_tracker.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib/commit/4c4d34b2b0d70e0c92f568a0080eff0df49f096f', 'message': "Handle missing launchpadlib gracefully

launchpadlib use not mandatory. The script will check if launchpadlib

Change-Id: I59814346e899e366734caaf757eb2d8fe5ecbcf7

commit_message:
Handle missing launchpadlib gracefully

The use of launchpadlib should not be required for tempest-lib, however
because we wanted to expose the skip_tracker as an entry point and
package it with the library an import to launchpadlib was needed in the
packaged source, which normally should require an entry in the
requirements file. This commit addresses that by making the
launchpadlib use not mandatory. The script will check if launchpadlib
is available and if it isn't the skip tracker will just exit after it
scans for the bug list.

Change-Id: I59814346e899e366734caaf757eb2d8fe5ecbcf7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib refs/changes/47/159147/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: from launchpadlib import launchpad except ImportError: launchpad = None if launchpad is not None: lp = launchpad.Launchpad.login_anonymously('grabbing bugs', 'production', LPCACHEDIR) else: print("To check the bug status launchpadlib should be installed") exit(0)
deleted_lines: from launchpadlib import launchpad lp = launchpad.Launchpad.login_anonymously('grabbing bugs', 'production', LPCACHEDIR)

commit_message:
Adds custom nova_host_aggregate and nova_host_aggregate_metadata types

Adds custom types for managing Nova host aggregates and metadata on host
aggregates.  Implemented using the nova command, so this type requires
authentication information.

Ultimately this should be implemented using direct API calls to Nova
(Aviator.)  But I think this is a "good enough" workable solution for
the time being until that's available.

Change-Id: If9038647e712628563b45be6e67b1a56d096c8d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/60/120460/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Puppet::Type.type(:nova_host_aggregate_metadata).provide(:nova) do desc "Manage metadata key=value pairs on Nova host aggregates" optional_commands :nova => 'nova' def nova_authd_call(*args) nova( "--os-username", resource[:username], "--os-password", resource[:password], "--os-tenant-name", resource[:tenant], "--os-auth-url", resource[:auth_url], args ) end def metadata_hash @metadata_hash ||= build_metadata_hash end def build_metadata_hash hash = {} aggr, key = resource[:name].split(':', 2) begin nova_authd_call("aggregate-details", aggr).each do |line| m = /^\|\s+[0-9A-Za-z-]+\s+\|\s+#{aggr}\s+\|\s+\S+\s+\|\s+[^\|]*\s+\|\s+([^\|]*)\s+\|/.match(line) if m pairs = m[1].split(/,\s?/).map{ |pair| pair.sub(/^'(.+)'$/, '\1') } pairs.each { |pair| key, value = pair.split('=', 2) hash["#{aggr}:#{key}"] = value } break end end rescue Puppet::ExecutionFailure # Nova command above will exit non-zero if the aggregate doesn't exist. # We want to silently ignore this. end hash end def create aggr, key = resource[:name].split(':', 2) nova_authd_call("aggregate-set-metadata", aggr, "#{key}=#{resource[:value]}") end def exists? metadata_hash[resource[:name]] end def destroy aggr, key = resource[:name].split(':', 2) nova_authd_call("aggregate-set-metadata", aggr, key) end def value metadata_hash[resource[:name]] end def value=(value) create end end

subject: Adds custom nova_flavor and nova_flavor_extraspec types
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-09 05:26:06.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/nova_flavor_extraspec/nova_manage.rb', 'lib/puppet/type/nova_flavor.rb', 'lib/puppet/provider/nova_flavor/nova_manage.rb', 'lib/puppet/type/nova_flavor_extraspec.rb', 'README.md'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/157e14ba3cf01b67e44d8575d501f0267f40764e', 'message': 'Adds custom nova_flavor and nova_flavor_extraspec types

Adds custom types for managing Nova flavors and extra spec data
on flavors.  Implemented using the nova-manage provider, similar to
nova_cells, nova_network, etc.

This is not implemented perfectly and there are caveats.
Specifically, there is a known issue where the nova-manage output
parsing will break if there is an extra spec key or value which
contains a comma, or both single and double quote characters.

Ultimately this should be implemented using direct API calls to
Nova (Aviator.)  But I think this is a "good enough" workable
solution for the interim time until that's available.

Change-Id: Ib73cb50e6ccccc010ab1155bbe86b3ca4695f8c5
'}]
commit_message:
Adds custom nova_flavor and nova_flavor_extraspec types

Adds custom types for managing Nova flavors and extra spec data
on flavors.  Implemented using the nova-manage provider, similar to
nova_cells, nova_network, etc.

This is not implemented perfectly and there are caveats.
Specifically, there is a known issue where the nova-manage output
parsing will break if there is an extra spec key or value which
contains a comma, or both single and double quote characters.

Ultimately this should be implemented using direct API calls to
Nova (Aviator.)  But I think this is a "good enough" workable
solution for the interim time until that's available.

Change-Id: Ib73cb50e6ccccc010ab1155bbe86b3ca4695f8c5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/97/119997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * nova_flavor_extraspec names or values containing a comma, or both double and single quote characters, will not work properly.

commit_message:
Fixed synchronous driver's import redirect

Recently all v2 drivers were moved to the neutron_lbaas.drivers package
from the neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.drivers package. To maintain
backwards compatibility with some of them, redirect of imports was
implemented for configs that have not updated to the new paths. the
synchronous_namespace_driver.py module's redirect is broken.

Change-Id: I35c5cb969a321417d176f37b8f49214ed62c4ae4
Closes-Bug: #1427539
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/77/160677/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class HaproxyNSDriver(synchronous_namespace_driver.HaproxyNSDriver): pass

commit_message:
Drop augtools from the tempest element

Since passthrough for tempest has been introduced, it is possible
for a section and/or a setting to appear more than once in
tempest.conf, which augtool cannot handle.

In fact it is not necessary to inject configuration settings, it
is fine to just append them to the config file, as the last
setting wins in any case.

Change-Id: Ie7bdb1d327c71a6b32d0b947d0f1764f9b14b40c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/67/150867/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fixed Kafka read error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-04 00:03:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-notification/commit/77efee764daf7c77586501ef5c7982c266c591a7', 'message': 'Fixed Kafka read error

If Kafka has to resize the partitions while the notification_engine is off then
once the notification_engine is restarted the kafka python library generates an
OffsetOutOfRangeError exception if our current location is no longer a valid
offset.  Now we trap the exception, seek to the front of the currently
available data, and resume processing from there.

Change-Id: I37b805265d042adddc2367fda8267f319b1acd2d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-04 00:28:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-notification/commit/da83349fe4f3b114d7f6737ec4f5e2427d22642f', 'message': 'Fixed Kafka read error

If Kafka has to resize the partitions while the notification_engine is off then
once the notification_engine is restarted the kafka python library generates an
OffsetOutOfRangeError exception if our current location is no longer a valid
offset.  Now we trap the exception, seek to the front of the currently
available data, and resume processing from there.

Change-Id: I37b805265d042adddc2367fda8267f319b1acd2d

commit_message:
Fixed Kafka read error

If Kafka has to resize the partitions while the notification_engine is off then
once the notification_engine is restarted the kafka python library generates an
OffsetOutOfRangeError exception if our current location is no longer a valid
offset.  Now we trap the exception, seek to the front of the currently
available data, and resume processing from there.

Change-Id: I37b805265d042adddc2367fda8267f319b1acd2d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-notification refs/changes/34/161034/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: for message in self._consumer: if not set_partitioner.acquired: break consumed_from_kafka += 1 log.debug("Consuming message from kafka, " "partition {}, offset {}". format(message[0], message[1].offset)) yield message except kafka.common.OffsetOutOfRangeError: self._consumer.seek(0, 0)
deleted_lines: for message in self._consumer: if not set_partitioner.acquired: break consumed_from_kafka += 1 log.debug("Consuming message from kafka, " "partition {}, offset {}".format(message[0], message[1].offset)) yield message

commit_message:
Faster calculation or RPM dependencies

Apparently yumdownloader handles conflicting packages just fine if asked
for download URLs only.

Change-Id: Ib949091866621c3e229ce7a69c4fdaf423872d4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/98/159098/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/urls.list: $(SOURCE_DIR)/requirements-rpm.txt \ $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/yum-config.done mkdir -p $(@D) && \ env \ TMPDIR="$(centos_empty_installroot)/cache" \ TMP="$(centos_empty_installroot)/cache" \ yumdownloader -q --urls \ --archlist=$(CENTOS_ARCH) \ --installroot="$(centos_empty_installroot)" \ -c $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/etc/yum.conf \ --resolve \ `cat $(SOURCE_DIR)/requirements-rpm.txt` > "$@.out" 2>"$@.log" sed -rne '/\.rpm$$/ {p}' < $@.out > $@.pre
deleted_lines: # By default yum uses /var/tmp/yum-$USER-xxyyzz as a meta-data cache. Use # a local directory to avoid old meta-data copies. Also makes it possible # to run several builds in parallel env \ TMPDIR='$(centos_empty_installroot)/cache' \ TMP='$(centos_empty_installroot)/cahce' \ yum --installroot=$(centos_empty_installroot) -c $< makecache # yum makecache does not load groups lists data, run some command which makes # use of group lists (and downloads them as a side effect) env \ TMPDIR='$(centos_empty_installroot)/cache' \ TMP='$(centos_empty_installroot)/cahce' \ yumdownloader -q --urls \ --archlist=$(CENTOS_ARCH) \ --installroot="$(centos_empty_installroot)" \ -c $< --resolve @Base @Core > /dev/nullrpm_download_lists:=$(REQUIRED_RPMS:%=$(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/lists/%.list)$(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/urls.list: $(rpm_download_lists) mkdir -p $(@D) cat $^ > $@.pre sed -rne '/\.rpm$$/ {p}' -i $@.pre# XXX: yumdownloader operates upon rpmdb so running several instances # concurrently (within the same installroot) is not safe. Create # an installroot template and make a shallow copy for every yumdownloader # process. Hard link the repository metadata too and tell yum to use that # (instead of /var/tmp/yum-$USER-xxyyzz) via TMP and TMPDIR environment # variables. $(rpm_download_lists): $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/lists/%.list: \ $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/yum-config.done \ $(SOURCE_DIR)/requirements-rpm.txt tmp_installchroot=$(dir $(centos_empty_installroot))installchroot-$*; \ cp -al "$(centos_empty_installroot)" "$$tmp_installchroot" && \ mkdir -p $(@D) && \ env \ TMPDIR="$$tmp_installchroot/cache" \ TMP="$$tmp_installchroot/cache" \ yumdownloader -q --urls \ --archlist=$(CENTOS_ARCH) \ --installroot="$$tmp_installchroot" \ -c $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/centos/etc/yum.conf \ --cacheonly \ --resolve $* > $@.tmp 2>$@.log && \ rm -rf "$$tmp_installchroot" && \ mv $@.tmp $@

commit_message:
requirements-deb.txt: skip the essential packages

Essential packages are downloaded automatically (mkrepo.sh takes care
of them), hence there's no need to list them in requirements-deb.txt

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: I2da805e0cff39d2b6f87d4289175b35e57a82282

commit_message:
mirror/ubuntu: speed up downloading the packages

Create an alternative APT config/state instead of making a chroot.
Guess the set of nonconflicting packages and process them in a batch.
Figure out the set of udebs to download using apt-cache instead of
parsing APT repository meta-data with shell code.

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: I6f3694c714bbaa488894857ce3a6d5c753197db7

commit_message:
image/ubuntu: speed up bulding image for provisioning

Bootstrap a system on a journal-less ext4 filesystem, and re-enable
journal afterwards (just before resizing the image).

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: I10d1490ee3cb83ad983742c66bdfa1622a603295
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/03/156903/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo tune2fs -O ^has_journal "${LOOP_DEV}" || die "Failed to configure filesystem" case "$FS_TYPE" in ext4) if ! sudo tune2fs -O has_journal "${LOOP_DEV}"; then die "Re-adding journal for ext4 filesystem on ${LOOP_DEV}" fi ;; esac sudo resize2fs -M ${LOOP_DEV} || die "Couldn't resize filesystem"

commit_message:
Handle SSL termination proxies for version list

Return correct scheme in version URLs if service
behind an SSL termination proxy.

Change-Id: I76462db9c01a130964844207e375bd35359694f7
Closes-Bug: 1370022
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/35/132235/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import urlparse env = context['environment'] scheme = env.get(CONF['secure_proxy_ssl_header']) if scheme: _, netloc, path, params, query, fragment =\ urlparse.urlparse(url) url = urlparse.urlunparse((scheme, netloc, path, params, query, fragment))
